name: Bosnia and Herzegovina
notes_H1: Ministry of Health has a public information site, with the first report published on January 31st. https://web.archive.org/web/20200416231119/https://covid19.fmoh.gov.ba/
notes_H2: 'Three Chinese citizens were admitted to the Sarajevo University Medical Centre and are being tested for the coronavirus, the head of the Centre, Sebija Izetbegovic, said at a press conference on Tuesday [25th February]'.       http://web.archive.org/web/20200416103146/https://balkaneu.com/several-suspicious-but-not-confirmed-cases-of-coronavirus-in-bih/
notes_C7: “Movement Restrictions: Is a curfew in place? No. Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No.” Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Cannot find a specific policy of school closure in any entities of the country  The new school year 2020/2021 in BiH started with combined teaching programmes (classroom teaching and online classes). Teaching is conducted in smaller groups of pupils, with shorter  classes and respect of strict sanitary rules (wearing masks is obligatory for teaching staff, and  recommended for pupils.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201024193117/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf
notes_H6: As of March 29, 2020, the Federation began requiring all persons on the street or in public areas to cover their mouth and nose with a mask or scarf; in the RS, all persons must also wear gloves in public.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201002061401/https://www.osac.gov/Country/BosniaHerzegovina/Content/Detail/Report/735ec25f-20ef-4ff9-bb52-1858fa23ff5b
notes_E2: Banking Agencies have announced a six-month loan repayment moratorium for restructuring credit arrangements for individuals and legal entities which are found to have aggravated circumstances for loans repayments due to COVID-19. Banking Agencies have instructed banks to track clients and exposure portfolios affected by COVID-19. Banks are also instructed to consider additional customer relief, including reviewing current fees for services and avoiding charging fees to handle exposure modifications. All banks were ordered not to pay dividends or bonuses.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: The RS also announced that the government will pay minimum salaries for all employees in these sectors in April (KM 53 million, 0.16 percent of GDP) and is planning to increase the transfers to unemployment funds (KM 25 million, 0.08 percent of GDP). The FBiH plans to subsidize contributions and taxes and pay minimum wages for all employees of the companies impacted by COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109060549/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:   Public gatherings of more than 30 people outdoors and indoors are prohibited. Parliament's sittings are excluded from this. Exceptionally, no more than 70 people may be present in theatres and cinemas. Organizers are obliged to register all planned events with the cantonal Ministry of Health. Competition activities for sports clubs and athletes may only take place without an audience.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Republika Srpska:   All public gatherings with more than 50 people are prohibited.  All private gatherings (weddings, baptisms and birthday parties, family meetings, etc.) with more than 10 people are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html    Brcko District: On 3 November, public gatherings in closed spaces were banned.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210102174538/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/bosniaandherzegovina/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section    (22 Nov) religious gatherings (funerals, holidays) as well as weddings limited to 30 persons.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829154713/http://www.ohr.int/report-on-measures-and-orders-adopted-during-the-pandemic-of-covid-19-in-bih/
notes_C6: Curfew from 23:00 - 05:00, with some exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210311094851/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C8: US Citizens and British Nationals, including those with residence in Bosnia and Herzegovina, need a negative COVID-19 (PCR) test result that is not older than 48 hours. Some groups are exempt from this rule, including: diplomats accredited to and resident in Bosnia and Herzegovina, EUFOR/NATO staff, freight drivers and crew, and foreigners in transit to their country of residence. Changes to restrictions may be introduced at short notice. You should comply with any screening measures put in place by the authorities. You should not use the NHS testing service to get a test in order to facilitate your travel to another country. You should arrange to take a private test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200921174139/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bosnia-and-herzegovina/entry-requirements  https://web.archive.org/web/20200829101240/https://ba.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  https://web.archive.org/save/https://blog.wego.com/covid19-travel-restrictions-by-destination-country/
notes_C2: Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina:  Night clubs and discos will remain closed until further notice. Restaurants are allowed to remain open until 11 p.m. All services must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them. From 5.11.2020, all legal persons, i.e. companies, in the Federation of Bosnia and Herzegovina are obliged to set flexible working hours in the work processes they perform and, where possible, to introduce teleworking.     Republika Srpska  All legal entities, i.e. companies, and public administration are invited to organise the work as a teleworking wherever possible. Opening hours for catering establishments are from 6 a.m. to 10 p.m., with live music prohibited. A minimum of 10 m2 of space must be available for each table with a maximum of 4 people. The opening hours of gambling operators (casinos, vending machines and similar ones) must be reduced to 10 p.m. The so-called "drugstores" (small grocery stores), which are usually open 24H, are only allowed to sell counters after 10 p.m. All shops and businesses must take additional hygiene measures and continuously disinfect them.    Brko District  From 7.12.2020, opening hours of catering establishments, fitness centres, gambling operators, sports schools are limited to 7 p.m.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210102162128/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_C4: Private gatherings restricted to max. 10 people. Up to 25 people for funerals.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210311094851/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-infos-bosnien-herzegowina.html
notes_H7: Officially vaccines to be delivered via Covax, but so far none have arrived. Vaccine donations from Serbia (of Sputnik and AZ vaccines) have been offered to key health workers (Group: A)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210311102959/https://www.voanews.com/covid-19-pandemic/bosnia-seeks-help-germany-acquiring-covid-19-vaccines-through-covax
notes_C5: According to OECD, in the FBiH the public transportation became operational again, meaning that public transport is now running across the whole country.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200528100802/https://www.oecd.org/south-east-europe/COVID-19-Crisis-in-Bosnia-and-Herzegovina.pdf

name: Belarus
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health is launching a campaign "New Year - Home Holiday" aimed at holding safe New Year holidays.  The purpose of the pre-holiday campaign is to convince the public of the need to comply with safety measures during the COVID-19 pandemic.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201228095550/https://www.belta.by/society/view/minzdrav-zapuskaet-aktsiju-novyj-god-domashnij-prazdnik-421644-2020/
notes_H3: 1st and 2nd level contacts being traced.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200517231426/https://news.tut.by/society/679921.html
notes_H2: more than 65,000 COVID-19 tests are currently available
notes_C1: "On Monday (20th), [the president] allowed the country’s schools to reopen after an extended spring break."  However, "[...] authorities allowed parents to keep their children at home even though the government has steered clear of closures and restrictions on public movement amid the country’s expanding coronavirus outbreak. [...]. As voluntary actions do not fall under the new C1 regulation, I've decided to keep the level on a general 0.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200517225810/https://www.clickondetroit.com/news/politics/2020/04/21/the-latest-the-coronavirus-cancels-oktoberfest-in-germany/  https://web.archive.org/web/20201105125231/https://apnews.com/article/3e53f7e4d840375c70f62847f968ad43
notes_H6: On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143542/https://news.tut.by/society/706859.html    On 5 November, Mogilev became the first city in Belarus to introduce compulsory use of facial masks in public places.    On 9 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Gomel Region.    According to the 11 November Ministry of Health decree, PCR-based tests were no longer conducted for first-level contacts with an asymptomatic infection course.    On 12 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Minsk. As of date, besides Minsk, Gomel Region and Mogilev, such measure was reported to had been employed in Babruisk, Asipovichy, Klichev, Krichev, Chavusy District, Cherykaw District, Polotsk District and Novopolotsk.    On 16 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Vitebsk Region.    On 18 November, compulsory use of facial masks was introduced in Brest Region.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201210143604/https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/COVID-19_pandemic_in_Belarus
notes_C3: No information to be found on actual recommendation/requirement of shutting down public events. There are, indeed, certain requirements on eg. distancing but no general rule to cancel.  That being said, The Ministry of Health decided on 6th of April to limit all cultural, sports and scientific events with !international! participation. Permission to hold other public events will be issued after assessing the availability of conditions for their holding. As mentioned earlier. Also, since 12th of March, places of general gathering of citizens are monitored for correct working ventilation shafts, the presence of antiseptics and compliance with other sanitary standards.  Link: https://archive.fo/g9cm7     ++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++++    No change in policy until early January 2021. It is recommended that fairs, exhibitions, presentations and other events are held with the observance of social distancing and the use of masks and gloves by staff.     As there seem to be no restrictions on event apart from ones with international participation, this could technically also be coded as "0"     https://web.archive.org/web/20201210134154/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/belarus/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.2+Physical+distancing&Type=Section
notes_C8: "President Alexander Lukashenko reportedly ordered the partial closure of Belarus' borders with Poland, Latvia, and Lithuania on (and from) Thursday, October 29, [...]. The extent of the new restrictions was not clear from Lukashenko's announcement, in which he claimed they had been introduced to reduce the spread of the coronavirus disease (COVID-19). However, Polish and Lithuanian authorities stated that foreign nationals had been barred from entering Belarus via their border crossings since 16:00 (local time), with only Belarusian nationals and freight traffic being permitted to cross the border. Lithuanian guards later reported that vehicles had also been prevented from crossing the border from the Belarus side. [...]    To better facilitate arrival, foreign nationals are encouraged to carry proof of a negative result for COVID-19 issued no more than 48 hours prior to departure using a polymerase chain reaction (PCR) test.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105140140/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/394851/belarus-government-introduces-restrictions-at-borders-with-poland-latvia-and-lithuania-october-29-update-64    "From October 29, 2020, all persons arriving in Belarus must self-isolate for 10 days upon arrival. This policy does not apply to persons arriving from the following countries / regions: Austria, Albania, China, Estonia, Finland, Germany, Greece, Hungary, Italy, Latvia, Monaco, Montenegro, Norway, Serbia, and Spain"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201105140647/https://www.trip.com/travel-restrictions-covid-19/
notes_H7: “A new stage starts in Belarus today with mass vaccinations (Sputnik V) against COVID-19. Medical staff and teachers, will be the first to get vaccinated (tachers later on, however, see below). Vaccination will be entirely voluntary,” Belarus Health Minister Dmitry Pinevich was quoted as saying in a statement issued by his ministry and Russian health authorities.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104125657/https://apnews.com/article/belarus-coronavirus-pandemic-latin-america-auto-racing-glance-russia-fcddcc286f8295421c0ff301c242dad0    "Now we continue vaccinating healthcare workers. We expect the next batch to arrive in the near future. Teachers will be next in line for a COVID-19 vaccine. In the first quarter of this year, we are set to release the Sputnik V vaccine under the Belarusian brand, together with Russian colleagues at the Belarus-based Belmedpreparaty pharmaceutical company,”    https://web.archive.org/web/20210120121234/https://eng.belta.by/society/view/minister-pneumonia-cases-keep-declining-in-belarus-136636-2021/    Unable to find evidence regarding funding so have recorded government funded for now, as vaccine is voluntary and only available to certain groups, suggesting that it couldn't be purchased privately (individually funded)

name: Belize
notes_H1: "The Ministry of Health advises the public to be guided by facts. To stay informed and updated on the evolving COVID-19 situation, follow the Facebook pages of the Ministry of Health, the Office of the Director of Health Services, and the Government Press Office.  The Ministry of Health will continue to provide timely updates as our response changes to this evolving situation."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200430161753/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1016-ministry-of-health-advisory-no-5--covid-19
notes_H3: Belmopan. March 25, 2020. The Ministry hereby provides a report on an initial mapping exercise in San Pedro Town, Ambergris Caye. The mapping exercise allowed the Ministry to test seven persons who were the immediate contacts of the index case. One immediate contact from those individuals resulted as a positive case. The patient is stable and has no signs or symptoms as of today. All other samples are negative. To date, there are two confirmed cases of COVID-19 in Belize. In addition, five other samples which were collected from two other districts all tested negative. As part of the ongoing enhanced surveillance, further tests which were collected today, March 25th, in San Pedro and other districts will be processed at the lab later today. The Ministry of Health will continue its enhanced public surveillance across the country. SOURCE: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402163923/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1029-covid-19-test-samples--update-no-1
notes_H2: "At this time COVID-19 testing is only being done people who have been identified through Ministry of Health contact mapping or present themselves with COVID-19 symptoms" - as of 1st Sept 2020
notes_C7: "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Tourists visiting Belize can move about freely, however it is recommended that they remain within the Tourism Safe Corridor.  The Safe Corridor includes Gold Standard certified accommodations, tour operators, tourism transportation providers, restaurants, tourism sites and attractions, and gift shops.  These Gold Standard and certified entities have all been trained and have implemented enhanced health and safety measures."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210312165455/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Starting on March 20, the PM and leader of opposition announced that all schools to be closed for 14 days leading into the Easter Break. Measures announced on March 17 following first meeting of the COVID-19 National Oversight Committee.    See Belize national press office for more information:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527181132/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/government-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19/
notes_H6: Statutory Instrument 65 states from 1st May:  "every person in a public place, public space, or public office or building shall wear a face mask or other face (mouth) covering;"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131649/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-65-of-2020-Belize-Constitution-1.pdf?fbclid=IwAR1NmEevhEGOZmhhy2t3FTQEY-FbCOwCm3gdn2-6cOtjd-9DzYbN2ho2BFM    https://web.archive.org/web/20200830131055/https://www.sanpedrosun.com/politics-and-government/2020/06/30/state-of-emergency-expires-certain-restrictions-remain/  "Peyrefitte added that the only time face masks can be excluded is when someone is at home, driving in their vehicle, persons participating in church services would not be required to wear masks but are asked to practice social distancing. Also a mask is not needed when eating at a restaurant, while exercising, and participating in sporting events, to name a few. In the case of face masks, failure to use them in public places can end in an arrest and charge."
notes_E2: "liquidity support through postponements of social security and tax payments for companies and self-employed"  https://web.archive.org/web/20200723165805/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: Belize has announced fiscal stimulus amounting to BZ$25 million (about 1 percent of GDP) in 2020 to provide short term relief to employees affected by the crisis, especially those in the tourism sector. So far, more than 40,000 applications for unemployment relief have been approved - as of August 27th, 2020.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913151000/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Effective cancellation of public events: "Effective immediately, social gatherings will be limited to 100 people. These include indoor and outdoor gatherings."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200426045826/http://health.gov.bz/www/component/content/article/177-general-health/1024-belize-announces-new-measures-in-response-to-covid-19
notes_C6: The stay at home order has been enhanced due to the increase in cases as per the US Embassy in Belize. People will be fined for being in public spaces, unless to visit select places.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210210012855/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: No longer require mandatory self-quarantine for any Belizean, permanent resident,  holder of a valid work permit, Qualified Retired Person,  the foreign homeowner or long stay non-national who enters  Belize through the airport due to repeal of Amendment 20, section 1 on October 19, 2020  Latest press release  http://web.archive.org/web/20201022043048/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-No-149-of-2020-Quarantine-rev.pdf  Regulations that this press release refers to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201022043541/https://www.pressoffice.gov.bz/wp-content/uploads/2019/12/SI-136-2020-Quarantine.pdf
notes_C2: The Government of Belize has announced that the nationwide State of Emergency ended on Friday 4 September. Regulations remain in force to prevent, control, contain and suppress the spread of coronavirus. Restaurants can open for delivery, take away or drive through only. Spas, beauty salons and barbershops are allowed to operate with appointment only subject to social distance protocols.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913115634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_C4: Churches, social events, and private parties that would include guests outside of the immediate family who are living together are not allowed as stated by US Embassy in Belize, updated on 1st September 2020.   The statutory instruments that set out the requirements in Belize, updated on 4th September 2020. It includes the restriction of no gatherings of more than 10 persons.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200902003040/https://bz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200913115634/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus
notes_C5: "Public transport is running with seated only capacity".    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314183422/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/belize/coronavirus

name: Bermuda
notes_H1: The Government of Bermuda began press releases to the general public on January 22, 2020. The Government has also released videos and resource materials.  Archived Source: /web/20200402155519/https://www.gov.bm/articles/current-threat-coronavirus-bermuda-residents-low
notes_H3: "The Ministry of Health can confirm that there are no cases or known suspect cases of the coronavirus currently in Bermuda....If a case of 2019-nCoV is confirmed in Bermuda, contact tracing will begin immediately and relevant individuals will be contacted by Ministry of Health staff.  Any situation posing a risk to the safety of the general public will be communicated through official Ministry of Health channels."  Archived Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200402184005/https://www.gov.bm/articles/coronavirus-update-ministry-health-0
notes_H2: The testing schedule is regularly updated. It no longer appears to be restricted to symptomatic patients.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201130003747/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-get-tested
notes_C7: No restrictions on internal movement    https://web.archive.org/web/20200916170209/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Public Schools reopened in-person learning on the 13th of January.     https://www.gov.bm/articles/eemc-public-schools-reopen-january-13th     http://web.archive.org/web/20210110213759/https://www.gov.bm/articles/eemc-public-schools-reopen-january-13th     Latest Covid-19 Guidelines for School Settings - http://web.archive.org/web/20210119005407/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/11436-Coronavirus-2020-School-Guidance%20%286%29.pdf     Latest guidance for Minibuses and Public Buses for dedicated school runs - http://web.archive.org/web/20210119005526/https://www.gov.bm/sites/default/files/11645_School%20Buses%20Phase%204%20200903.pdf
notes_H6: Masks must be worn indoors, but outdoors only when physical distancing cannot be maintained.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017211320/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-phase4-guidance
notes_E2: No documentation suggests that utilities disconnection protection remains in place. Debt relief appears to have been reduced to 0.
notes_E1: The extent of the government's employment assistance is not immediately clear. It appears to have extended the length of unemployment benefits, and has also created an additional benefit for those whose unemployment assistance expires. Nevertheless it does not appear that this assistance is equivalent to a large proportion of lost wages, and given that it expires, the coding has been changed to 1F.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201017213810/https://www.gov.bm/articles/financial-assistance-supplemental-unemployment-benefit    This article notes that a number of people remain on unemployment assistance, indicating that measures remain active.  https://www.royalgazette.com/letters-to-the-editor/article/20201003/slippery-slope-towards-banana-republicanism/
notes_C3: The maximum permitted number of people in any group will be reduced further to ten. http://web.archive.org/web/20201215001740/https://www.gov.bm/articles/ministerial-statement-covid-19-%E2%80%93-need-further-action
notes_C6: Curfew has ended but bars are required to close at 11pm.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210222195057/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/bermuda/coronavirus  https://archive.vn/zmPiN
notes_C8: Residents /Visitors are required to quarantine at home or in their accommodation until they receive a negative arrival test.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201028234041/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-travellers   http://web.archive.org/web/20201028235035/https://bm.usconsulate.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Bars and nightclubs can re-open but will only be permitted to operate as table service only, with a maximum of 6 at a table. No bar service will be permitted.  Effective 21st January 2021.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210201232618/https://www.gov.bm/nightclubs-and-bars-guidance
notes_C4: Persons must not gather in groups of more than 25 persons, whether in public or private.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210201231644/http://www.bermudalaws.bm/laws/Annual%20Laws/2021/Statutory%20Instruments/Public%20Health%20%28COVID-19%20Emergency%20Powers%29%20%28No.%203%29%20Amendment%20%28No.%202%29%20Regulations%202021.pdf     http://web.archive.org/web/20210201231802/https://www.gov.bm/coronavirus-phase4-guidance
notes_H7: A,C.     12,000 Pfizer/BioNTech vaccines administered.     The National COVID-19 Vaccine Distribution Plan is in the final stages of completion in preparation for the arrival of the first batch of AstraZeneca vaccines. The AstraZeneca vaccine will be administered in two doses.  These COVID-19 vaccines will be available free of charge.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210222203159/http://www.tribune242.com/news/2021/feb/22/dont-be-afraid-pm-urges-public-accept-vaccination-/
notes_C5: The Department of Public Transportation (DPT) announced the bus service will resume daily operations from December 17.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210119021539/https://www.loopnewscaribbean.com/content/bermuda-bus-service-resumes-today-after-closure-due-covid-case

name: Bolivia
notes_H1: Governmental line to give people information over corona.  "The National Government presented today the number of the toll free line 800-10-1104 for the attention and consultations of the population about the coronavirus."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729150003/https://www.minsalud.gob.bo/3974-gobierno-habilita-linea-gratuita-800-10-1104-para-consultas-sobre-el-coronavirus
notes_H3: No update: /web/20201127175129/https://vea.global/category/bolivia/
notes_H2: PCR tests widely available but antigen testing still unavailable. Regulation of COVID-19 testing subject to Servicio Departamental de Salud (SEDES)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215173137/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: No internal movement restrictions     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308151050/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Schools reopen - departments and municipalities will have the authority to determine schedules. Public health precautions in place where face-to-face teaching has began. Learning schedules and adoption of blended learning depending on epidemiological situation in each region   https://web.archive.org/web/20210215171816/https://fotos.europapress.es/actualidadinternacional/f3559128/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210215172253/https://www.republicworld.com/world-news/south-america/school-begins-in-bolivia-amid-coronavirus-spike.html
notes_H6: Required in all public places   https://web.archive.org/web/20201218104825/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: No additional allocation of debt/contract relief   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: The government announced economic benefits. A "family basket" of 400 Bolivians in cash that will be provided to those who are on welfare and a family bonus of 500 Bolivians for families with children in kinder garden and elementary school. Both policies will reach 7 million Bolivian citizens.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200731162440/https://www1.abi.bo/abi_/?i=447684
notes_C3: Cultural, sporting, social and religious activities, electoral and recreational processes that generate crowds are permitted subject to biosecurity measures.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C
notes_C6: Curfew not in place.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210110112457/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Restrictions on working hours have been lifted and commercial activities are permitted to operate on a continuous basis.   Departmental and municipal governments will determine commercial activity and other services not governed by the national decree and may add restrictions as needed by local conditions.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201207184300/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C
notes_C4: Suspension of restrictions    http://web.archive.org/web/20201207174911/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H7: A,B,C; Sputnik-V & Sinopharm     'According to the vaccination report issues by Ministry of Health and Sports, until Friday March 5, 10,325 of the first dose and 9,785 of the second dose of the Sputnik-V vaccine and 83,075 does of Sinopharm (first dose) provided.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210308154542/https://www.minsalud.gob.bo/5350-ministro-auza-la-inmunizacion-contra-la-covid-19-avanza-satisfactoriamente-con-la-aplicacion-de-10-mil-vacunas-al-dia
notes_C5: "Public transport is operating, though social distancing and the use of masks in public vehicles places remains obligatory"   http://web.archive.org/web/20201207174911/https://bo.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Brazil
notes_H1: With the end of the electoral period, subnational governments whose social media pages had been suspended have returned to post about COVID-19.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201208045118/https://docs.google.com/document/d/1XLX-hT-NffQ86QK6T8-JECh4mIwVtOC2kCIFMHZZTac/edit
notes_H3: On 1 April, the Federal Government launched the "TeleSUS" aiming to inform and diagnose the population. It provides information and offers remote medical consultation through an app, a chat on the Health Ministery website, or a phone call. In the latter, through automatic phone calls to the population, the government tracks people with symptoms or who had contact with the virus. 4,8 million people had received a phone call by 19 April.    Links:   https://web.archive.org/web/20200731003404/https://www.saude.gov.br/noticias/agencia-saude/46734-teleatendimento-mais-de-2-milhoes-de-pessoas-ja-utilizaram-os-servicos-do-telesus    https://web.archive.org/web/20200731003457/https://www1.folha.uol.com.br/colunas/viniciustorres/2020/04/como-vai-ser-o-primeiro-programa-nacional-de-caca-ao-coronavirus.shtml
notes_H2: Due to resource scarcity, some regions have been restricting eligibility.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210112035554/https://g1.globo.com/mg/minas-gerais/noticia/2020/12/23/governo-reduz-testagem-para-covid-19-em-minas-e-diz-que-so-tera-insumos-em-janeiro.ghtml
notes_C7: Since March 17, transport between the state of Rio de Janeiro and all other states with confirmed cases of coronavirus: /web/20200425161648/https://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/saude/noticia/2020-03/witzel-prorroga-por-mais-15-dias-o-isolamento-social-no-rio-de-janeiro
notes_C1: In Londrina (PR), a judicial decision determined private schools should be closed. All schools had been closed by the city government, but private ones were authorized by a court order to reopen on October 19.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201201040124/https://g1.globo.com/pr/norte-noroeste/noticia/2020/11/25/justica-determina-suspensao-de-aulas-presenciais-em-escolas-particulares-de-londrina.ghtml
notes_H6: On August 19, Bolsonaro’s veto was overturned by the Brazilian Congress.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201020074536/https://www12.senado.leg.br/noticias/materias/2020/08/19/derrubado-veto-de-bolsonaro-ao-uso-obrigatorio-de-mascara-na-pandemia
notes_E2: No information on debt/contract relief was found.
notes_E1: The 600 Reais monthly support (Emergency Aid or Auxilio Emergencial) ended on Dec 29th, when the last payment was made.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210112034206/https://g1.globo.com/economia/auxilio-emergencial/noticia/2020/12/29/pagamentos-do-auxilio-emergencial-chegam-ao-fim-nesta-terca-renda-cidada-ou-novo-auxilio-seguem-incertos.ghtml
notes_C3: Federal District cancells all events with an audience of more than 100 people. Link: https://www.agenciabrasilia.df.gov.br/2020/03/12/gdf-inclui-medidas-preventivas-no-decreto-de-combate-ao-coronavirus/
notes_C6: In Teresina the city government determined lockdown on sundays.    Link:     https://web.archive.org/web/20200915023744/https://g1.globo.com/pi/piaui/noticia/2020/09/09/lockdown-parcial-sera-mantido-aos-domingos-em-teresina-anuncia-prefeito.ghtml
notes_C8: From 29 July, Brazil has officially reopened its borders to international travel, which had been banned since March. However, an additional 30 days ban on the entry of foreigners by land (unless for transit) and sea has been extended.    The borders are open to nationals, residents, and tourists. Non-resident foreigners can enter for a period not exceeding 90 days and must show proof of the purchase of valid health insurance in Brazil with coverage for the entire period of travel. This insurance is required for each of the passengers traveling to Brazil, however, does not apply to:    * Brazilian citizens  * Foreigners residing in Brazil  * International transit passengers (as long as they remain in the departure lounge)    Official announcement (Portuguese):  http://web.archive.org/web/20200809164216/https://pesquisa.in.gov.br/imprensa/jsp/visualiza/index.jsp?jornal=600&pagina=1&data=29%2F07%2F2020&totalArquivos=1    Official source (English):  http://archive.fo/sf6aX    News coverage (English):  http://web.archive.org/web/20200809164424/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-brazil-travel/update-1-brazil-reopens-international-flights-to-tourists-even-as-coronavirus-deaths-spike-idUSL2N2F036J
notes_C2: The cities of Bage and Pelotas were classified as “very high risk” (phase black) in the state of Rio Grande do Sul’s reopening plan. Non-essential businesses should be closed.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201227063828/https://g1.globo.com/rs/rio-grande-do-sul/noticia/2020/12/11/pela-primeira-vez-rs-tem-bandeira-preta-no-mapa-do-distanciamento-controlado.ghtml
notes_C4: No news on restrictions under 10 people were found. Restrictions on private gatherings vary across the country: 50 people in PA and Curitiba (PR), and 100 people in SP.       Links:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302124623/https://agenciapara.com.br/noticia/24703/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210302124710/https://www.gazetadopovo.com.br/parana/decretos-curitiba-parana-divergem-limites-pessoas/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210302125041/https://sao-paulo.estadao.com.br/noticias/geral,doria-detalha-quarentena-mais-rigida-contra-covid-no-estado-de-sp-acompanhe,70003626486
notes_H7: Doses of CoronaVac arived in other states and vaccination started in the states of Rio de Janeiro, Santa Catarina, Goiás, Piauí, Mato Grosso do Sul, Maranhão, Espírito Santo, Tocantins, Minas Gerais, Ceará, Pernambuco, Mato Grosso, Paraná, Amazonas, and Rio Grande do Sul.    	There are basically four priority groups: (i) people over 60 in LTCF’s; (ii) institutions for people with disabilities; (iii) indigenous communities; (iv) health care workers (C, B, A).    Links:    https://web.archive.org/web/20210202035934/https://noticias.uol.com.br/saude/ultimas-noticias/redacao/2021/01/18/cinco-estados-e-o-distrito-federal-receberam-vacinas-contra-a-covid-19.htm     https://web.archive.org/web/20210202040912/https://agenciabrasil.ebc.com.br/saude/noticia/2021-01/apos-sp-goias-piaui-e-santa-catarina-iniciam-vacinacao
notes_C5: In RN, a decree issued by the state government authorized changes in the bus fleet (increase, reduction or changes in the schedules) to avoid agglomerations.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302130229/https://g1.globo.com/rn/rio-grande-do-norte/noticia/2021/02/27/covid-19-prefeitura-de-natal-determina-fechamento-de-orla-durante-finais-de-semana-para-evitar-aglomeracoes.ghtml       In Palmas (TO), the city government determined transportation should operate at 50% capacity.    Link:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210302130646/https://g1.globo.com/to/tocantins/noticia/2021/02/26/prefeitura-suspende-aulas-presenciais-e-limita-lotacao-no-transporte-publico-apos-aumento-dos-casos-de-covid-19.ghtml

name: Barbados
notes_H1: Original "Barbados has established a COVID-19 information hotline that can be reached at 246-536-4500. Archived Source: /web/20200402213119/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/ Information is being posted on the Government Information Service website, with a special web page dedicated to COVID-19. Archived Source: /web/20200402213250/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/extracts-emergency-management-covid-19-order-2020-fbclidiwar32cxrvq5zqfy0msm6nybss1_90a-nygoo3isvesndcghk-wagaik1dz48/"   Dowling - Updating with new source since the two two above seem unrelated. Jan 22 report from Barbados Ministry of Health: https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/health-ministry-on-alert-for-new-coronavirus/
notes_H3: "The Ministry has initiated the process of contact tracing to identify every individual who came in close contact with all cases and will quarantine such persons for 14 days. They will also be tested for COVID-19 if they become symptomatic."  Archived Source: /web/20200402230214/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/two-new-covid-19-cases-in-barbados/
notes_H2: "With 27,000 COVID-19 tests and 2,800 swabs secured by the Barbados government, the Ministry of Health intends to increase significantly the number of persons being tested for the virus. Health officials were forced to establish a rigid criteria when testing first began in February and also had to reduce the number of tests conducted in the last three to four days due to limited testing resources but this will be changed going forward." Source: http://www.loopnewsbarbados.com/content/moh-mass-testing-covid-19-commence-shortly
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel, and there is no curfew in place. Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200830212325/https://bb.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: Public schools resumed with online classes on January 18th. Barbados Community College also returned to online classes on January 22nd.  sources:  https://archive.vn/h9AXR  https://archive.vn/Jzwkf
notes_H6: Face masks now required in all public spaces.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207205308/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/download/official-gazette-february-1-2021-part-a-no-14/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207191256/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/blog/highlights-of-curfew-directives-from-feb-3-to-17/
notes_E2: No evidence of a policy change.  "Banks are now working with individual borrowers as needed on further repayment extensions."  source:  https://archive.vn/bZZSM
notes_E1: "Social Security Deferral – Deferral of employer’s contributions to the NIS for  employers retaining more than 2/3 of staff complement; Government will provide supplemental support to the NIS Unemployment Fund as needed and within the context of available fiscal space;  Laid off workers to receive benefits for 6 months and those on short weeks to receive 60% for the days they are not working . Welfare Support – Government, through the welfare department, to provide minimum income of an amount up to USD300 per month to households where no person is left employed as a result of COVID-19." GDP Per Capita in Barbados is around $16,000 which classafies this as limited support.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200604145001/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/barbados-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200604152540/https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/NY.GDP.PCAP.PP.CD?locations=BB
notes_C3: From January 2nd until January 14th, no person shall host or attend:  a party;  (b) a recreational or competitive sporting event;  (c) a banquet, ball, dance or reception;  (d) a meeting of a fraternal society, private or social club or   civic association or organization;  (e) the social event known as  (i) "a bus crawl"; or  (ii) "a lime";  (f) a karaoke event;  (g) a picnic; or  (h) a bus or other vehicular excursion  source:  https://archive.vn/kOBRg
notes_C6: Curfew in place between midnight and 5 am beginning on December 31st.  source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20210103175958/https://gisbarbados.gov.bb/download/emergency-management-covid-19-protocol-no-4-amendment/
notes_C8: Barbados Ministry of Tourism’s updated travel protocols came into effect on August 3rd.   These protocols state that “persons from High-Risk countries with a valid negative COVID-19 PCR test result will be quarantined at a designated holding hotel or approved villa at their own expense, or free of charge at a government facility, and will be monitored daily for the onset of symptoms. These persons will be quarantined for a period of 14 days with an option to take a second COVID-19 PCR test between 5-7 days after the last test accepted by the Ministry of Health and Wellness. Persons will typically be released once the test result is negative.” “High-Risk: Includes USA, Brazil, India, Mexico, Argentina, Peru, Colombia, South Africa, Indonesia, Philippines and Russia.”  Countries not classified as High-Risk, unless within the “Bubble”, which includes “Saint Lucia, St. Kitts & Nevis, Grenada, Dominica and St. Vincent & The Grenadines”, are required to take a COVID-19 PCR test prior to or on arrival.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200830211314/https://www.visitbarbados.org/covid-19-travel-guidelines-2020
notes_C2: "Effective March 1, several nonessential businesses that were previously ordered to close, may reopen including in the food, manufacturing, cleaning, professional services, construction, delivery services, and financial sectors, subject to health protocols."  source: https://archive.vn/KE5Ce
notes_C4: From January 2nd until January 14th:  "A person may only visit a beach or a park for the purpose of   swimming or exercise and, in the case of a group of persons, such  persons shall be from the same household and shall not exceed 10  persons."  source:  https://archive.vn/kOBRg
notes_H7: A,B,C  Vaccines available to those above 70 years and those age 18-69 with non-communicable diseases beginning February 17th. Frontline workers were initially the only group receiving the vaccine. The Oxford Astra Zeneca vaccine is being administered.  source: https://archive.vn/bamSy  https://archive.vn/wT0Qo
notes_C5: The Barbados government published the 'Emergency Management (COVID-19)  Protocol (No. 4) Directive, 2020' on 29th October 2020. Measures outlined will apply between the 29th October, 2020 and the 27th March, 2021.    While the measures allow public transport to operate with its authorised number of seated passengers, only half the number of authorised standing passengers are allowed on the vehicle.    https://drive.google.com/file/d/120tlIBURJq4vvzEgG4UR5khtz-N9jxXJ/view

name: Brunei
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health has a website with all relevant information on Coronavirus. It also brings statements to the population often.  Campaign website: /web/20200404203230/http://www.moh.gov.bn/SitePages/COVID-19.aspx  According to this source, campaign started on January 6: /web/20200404203313/https://sites.google.com/site/weechiankoh/home/Covid-19
notes_H3: It is also a legal requirement for all visitors and residents in Brunei to use the contact-tracing app BruHealth every time they enter/exit a public place. https://web.archive.org/web/20201025200552/https://thescoop.co/2020/10/23/coronavirus-one-new-imported-case-but-no-local-transmission-for-169-days/
notes_H2: Information from Ministry on Health on general charges for RT-PCR tests for citizen or foreign travelers, effective August 14, 2020.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201219023333/http://www.moh.gov.bn/Shared%20Documents/2019%20ncov/Swab%20charges_website_14082020.pdf
notes_C7: Members of the public are still required to comply with physical distancing guidelines even when businesses and public services return to full operations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_C1: All schools, including tertiary education institutions, can resume the “normal academic term” in the final phase of reopening from July 27, the education minister said.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729111541/https://thescoop.co/2020/07/23/brunei-proceeds-to-final-phase-of-de-escalation-plan-on-july-27/
notes_H6: “It is mandatory for those serving food, whether in fast food outlets or restaurants. They are the ones who should be using face masks.” Students it is recommended, and it will be mandatory during an outbreak in an area  https://web.archive.org/web/20200830144253/https://borneobulletin.com.bn/2020/06/face-masks-mandatory-for-food-servers-not-for-students/
notes_E2: Brunei Ministry of Finance and Economy announces the following policies for businesses and individuals effective April 1, 2020, applicable until March 31, 2021: (1) Extend deferment on principal repayments of financing, (2) Restructuring or deferring principal repayment of personal loan and hire purchase for a period not exceeding 10 years, (3) Deferment on principal repayments of property financing, (4) Converting any outstanding credit card balances into term loan not exceeding 3 years, (5) All bank fees and charges related will be waived.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201119013410/https://www.mofe.gov.bn/Press%20Room/Press%20Release%2030.03.2019%20%5BEnglish%5D%20-%20Interim%20Measures%20to%20Assist%20all%20the%20Business%20Sectors%20During%20COVID-19.pdf
notes_E1: No Income support provided as of now, it was provided until June 2020  Refer to:  https://web.archive.org/web/20200425202332/https://thescoop.co/2020/03/13/covid-19-live-updates/
notes_C3: Six types of premises will be allowed to reopen on May 16, including restaurants, gyms and sports facilities, driving schools as well as stalls and markets as part of the government’s “de-escalation plan” to ease coronavirus restrictions. While eateries, markets and sports facilities are now allowed to reopen, they are only permitted host 30 percent of their capacity at any one time.  /web/20200521022736/https://thescoop.co/2020/05/01/covid-19-live-updates-3/
notes_C8: Moving the code from 2 to 4, as entry into Brunei remains severely limited for foreigners from all countries, including Singapore (which has a Reciprocal Green Lane' agreement with Brunei - however, visitors from Singapore are only allowed in on essential business trips and via the same Entry Travel Pass requirements imposed on all other foreigners) except those entering for essential purposes (see Entry Travel Pass requirements).    Per the Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory,    "The Bruneian government has imposed an entry ban on all foreign visitors (non-Brunei citizens/non-Brunei permanent residents), including transit passengers, from 24 March 2020 until further notice. Foreign visitors seeking to enter Brunei must receive prior approval from the Brunei Department of Immigration and National Registration."    Per the US Embassy in Brunei's website, last updated 5 Mar, foreigners that do not have a valid reason to enter are banned from entering.    Are U.S. citizens permitted to enter?  No.  Effective September 15, 2020, foreign citizens who meet certain requirements may enter Brunei for essential travel only.  All other foreign citizens are barred from entering or transiting Brunei by air, land, or sea.  Visit the website of the Prime Minister’s Office for the latest information.  Citizens, permanent residents, and other residents of Brunei, including foreign citizens who hold a green identity card, require approval from the Prime Minister’s Office in order to leave the country. This policy does not apply to tourists or other visitors who do not hold Bruneian government-issued identity cards.  Residents may apply for permission to leave the country by completing an online application at the website of the Prime Minister’s Office.  Travelers should be prepared for additional travel restrictions to be put into effect with little to no advance notice. Visit the website of the Brunei Ministry of Health for the latest information.    Per the Ministry of Health,   From 20 March 2020, all passengers arriving in Brunei Darussalam  through any points of entry are required to undergo mandatory selfisolation for 14 days at a government-designated facility immediately  upon arrival to the country.  i) Self-isolation at private homes are not permitted.  ii) This include all visitors and foreign workers arriving in the  country.  iii) All foreign nationals including foreign workers arriving in the  country are required to bear fully the cost of mandatory selfisolation (including accommodation and meals) and laboratory  test for SARS-CoV-2 ($1000 per test).  iv) Foreign workers must submit special entry application for foreign  workers before arriving in Brunei Darussalam.     Per the Entry Travel Pass requirements, last updated 02 Oct 2020,    The Entry Travel Pass may be issued for the following individuals:  • Essential business travel (including official travel)  • Students  • Individual primarily here for the purpose of medical treatment  • Compassionate and other special circumstances, such as parents, spouse, or other  immediate family members of Brunei Citizens or Residents.  Applications will be reviewed for considerations on a case-to-case basis by authorities.    See Ministry of Foreign Affairs Singapore's travel advisory, archived at https://archive.vn/pQ2MH  See the US Embassy in Brunei's website, archived at https://archive.vn/fnAPh  See the Ministry of Health's guidelines on travel, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/mpd9geybded3b1h/BRN-undated-Guidelines_Travel.pdf  See the Prime Minister Office's guidelines on Entry Travel Pass applications, archived on Dropbox at https://www.dropbox.com/s/j0vr278nkt9dfh4/BRN-20201002-PMO-Guidelines_EntryTravelPassApp.pdf
notes_C2: From 17th August 2020 onwards, Cinemas will proceed to the third stage of reopening, operating at 80 percent of its full capacity compared to 60 percent in the second phase, and children will be allowed to go to cinemas. Cinemagoers must be kept one seat apart but family members can sit together.  Buffet restaurants will reopen, however only restaurant employees who wear protective face masks can serve food to the patrons. There is no capacity limit for dine-in at restaurants, cafés and food courts since the fourth phase of de-escalation plan took effect.  indoor and outdoor playgrounds as well as game arcades can operate at 60 percent of their normal capacity.  Museums, exhibition galleries and public libraries will also move to the final stage of reopening, hosting a maximum number of 100 people at a time as opposed to the previous 70 people.  For senior citizen centres, attendance is capped at 80 percent at a specific time – an increase from 60 percent.  Under the third phase of de-escalation plan, swimming pools are allowed to operate every day with no age restrictions and can accommodate 80 percent of its total capacity.  Visitors of swimming pools can use the facilities up to two hours a day.  The ministry has also increased the number of people allowed to train for team sports from 10 to 15 people.  Special needs centres and childcare facilities will be able to resume full operations next Monday as part of the fourth phase of de-escalation plan, said the minister of culture, youth and sports. Children of all ages can return to childcare centres, except those who display flu symptoms such as fever or are at high risk of developing a severe infection.  Special needs centres are also open to all, excluding those with chronic diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/
notes_C4: On 13th August 2020, the Government raised the limit of people at public and social gatherings from 100 to 200 people at a time.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200817154003/https://thescoop.co/2020/08/13/govt-announces-further-easing-of-covid-19-curbs/

notes_H6: "As essential health services are key for the sustenance of life and in an attempt to ease access to such services, the National COVID-19 Task Force today approved a protocol for availing essential health services during lockdowns.  The approved protocol will henceforth be applied during all lockdowns irrespective of their scale and magnitude.  The Ministry of Health urges all Bhutanese to kindly follow the attached protocol for availing the services through the essential health focal points which have been identified for all the 20 districts.  However, please note that everyone availing these services particularly in the health facilities should strictly abide by the following preventive measures:  1. Practice good physical distancing,  2. Wear a face mask at all times and  3. Wash hands frequently with soap and water or use a alcohol based hand rub from time to time." notes_E2: The Royal Monetary Authority (RMA) is working with the financial institutions to defer the loan repayment period and waive interest payments for three months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200607175452/https://www.royalkidu.bt/royal-address/index.html
notes_E1: The government announced a National Resilience Fund for mitigating COVID-19 linked to job losses and salary cuts. The support included grant for individuals directly affected by the pandemic and full interest waiver on loans contracted since April 10, 2020 until June 2020. These measures were extended until September 2020, and partial (50 percent) interest waiver will continue until March 2021.  Investments in GovTech is allowing Bhutan to reap benefits during COVID-19 including fast disbursement of cash relief funds.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208102716/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  The Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu was launched on 14 April 2020 to provide income support to individuals whose livelihoods were affected because of the COVID-19 pandemic. Between April and September 2020, Nu.1.2 billion was granted to over 33,000 beneficiaries and over 14,000 children.    The Relief Kidu has been extended for three months, from October to December 2020. Individuals who applied for or received Kidu in Phase I and/or Phase II need to re-apply for further assessments. Applications are also open to new applicants who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic.  Who is eligible?  Bhutanese who have been displaced by the coronavirus pandemic and are currently residing in Bhutan are eligible for the Druk Gyalpo’s Relief Kidu. The displaced group includes those who have been laid off, placed on unpaid leave or on reduced pay from businesses *** as well as self-employed individuals *** who have lost their earnings either partially or completely.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201208103817/https://royalkidu.bt/

For conferences, seminars, workshops and training, a maximum of only 25 people are allowed to gather.  The COVID-19 safety focal officers must maintain proper record of the attendees. notes_C6: the battle is only half won as we continue to sail through the pandemic, that too amid peak winter. We could regress into a situation far more disastrous if we let our guards down today.  Therefore, concerted efforts are being made to heighten surveillance along the borders and entry points with enhanced vigilance and improved operating procedures.  More tests for COVID-19 will be conducted among business communities, drivers, frontliners, students and health workers, while flu clinics will always scan for the early signs of the disease. Additional mobile flu clinics will be introduced in busy public places and certain points along the highways.  Above all, we are anticipating the roll out of the nationwide COVID-19 vaccination program that will protect our people and enable us to prevent the outbreak of the disease as we venture forward.  http://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.bt/covid19/29-01-21-press-release-on-unlocking-thimphu-and-beyond-starting-monday-february-1-2021-pmo/

name: Botswana
notes_H1: Social media and gov communication providing information, phone number for public questions, and prevention strategies. https://www.facebook.com/OFFICIAL.MOHW.BW/
notes_H3: CONTACT TRACING   Purpose  This document provides the steps needed to systematically monitor persons at high risk  for COVID-19 infection, as well as to conduct contact tracing of COVID-19 cases in  Botswana, and contacts whom they may have exposed to the disease. In conjunction  with active case finding and testing, and in synergy with other measures such as physical  distancing, contact tracing is recommended in all transmission scenarios.  According to current knowledge, COVID 19 is passed from one person to another primarily  through droplet transmission. People in close contact with COVID-19 cases are at high  risk of being infected with COVID-19, and, if infected, may also transmit the infection to  others. This guideline details how once a COVID-19 case has been identified, the Ministry  of Health and Wellness (MoHW) through District Health Management Teams (DHMT) and  other implementing partners will track, trace and manage people who may have been  exposed to COVID-19.  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923115019/https://covid19portal.gov.org.bw/sites/default/files/2020-05/COVID-19-Contact-Tracing-Guideline.pdf
notes_H2: No change.   Botswana has limited testing capacity. Testing regulations and information change frequently. If you are in Botswana and experiencing symptoms, contact your physician and the Government of Botswana COVID hotline at 997 for instructions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201028021025/https://bw.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

notes_E1: Key Policy Responses as of March 4, 2021  The government established a COVID-19 Relief Fund with a 2 billion Pula (about 1.1 percent of GDP) contribution from the government that will: i) finance a wage subsidy amounting to 50% of salaries of affected businesses (1000-2500 pula per month for a period of 3 months; ii) finance a waiver on training levy for a period of 6 months (150 million pula). The MoF also decided a tax deferral of 75% of any quarterly payment between March and September 2020 to be paid by March 2021.; iii) Build-up of fuel and grain reserves, as well as acquisition of relevant medical equipment and improvement of water supply (475 million Pula); iv) Fund a government loan guarantee scheme of 1 billion Pula (20% financed by commercial banks) for businesses that are tax compliant (including those who are not eligible to pay taxes/). Guarantee covers a period of 24 months with a max of 25 billion pula per borrower. Reduce the VAT refund period (from 60 days to 21 days).  https://web.archive.org/web/20210315081515/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Informal public events prohibited, maximum 50 persons in meetings, societies, funerals, faith-based services etc.     State of Public Emergency in place from September until the end of March, see earlier gazetted guidelines (https://web.archive.org/web/20210222203002/https://www.caab.co.bw/wp-content/uploads/Government-Gazette-Extraordinary.pdf).

After arrival, you will have to remain in contact with the local health authority for a period of 14 days for self-monitoring.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210108155848/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/botswana/entry-requirements

name: Central African Republic
notes_H1: "More than one million people informed about COVID-19 and barrier gestures  In addition to the assistance given to communities, more than 900 community, religious or civil society leaders, weapon bearers, local authorities or community members were alerted to the dangers of the disease in order that they in turn can pass on the right information. They learned handwashing technique and received posters, leaflets, handwashing equipment, kettles and soap so that they can launch and continue awareness-raising activities in their communities"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200903150029/https://www.icrc.org/en/document/central-african-republic-contending-covid-19-midst-serious-humanitarian-crisis
notes_H3: no mention of contract tracing in notices - https://web.archive.org/web/20210112215920/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/entry-requirements
notes_H2: The Central African Republic’s authorities have adopted a response plan for the health sector and enacted social distancing measures, including the closing of borders, schools, and most public establishments, a ban on meetings of more than 15 people, and restrictions on the movement of people from Bangui.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514181918/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    14 March 2020  WHO and the Ministry of Health and Population have already started raising awareness among the population on COVID-19, things to know, the importance of not giving in to panic and d '' observe the simple steps to prevent the disease, namely: wash your hands regularly with soap and water, cough or sneeze into the crease of the elbow or into a handkerchief to be thrown away immediately in a closed bin, keep a distance social at least one meter, avoid touching your eyes, nose and mouth or call the alert number of the Ministry of Health and Population, 1212, to report suspected cases.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515205656/https://www.afro.who.int/fr/news/la-republique-centrafricaine-rca-declare-un-premier-cas-de-covid-19    18 March 2020  A risk communication plan was developed for the Central African Republic.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200515204155/https://apps.who.int/iris/bitstream/handle/10665/331487/SITREP_COVID-19_WHOAFRO_20200318-eng.pdf    26 March 2020  An initial national prevention and response plan, focusing on public interventions was released in March and activities are ongoing. Prevention measures announced by the President on 26 March include the temporary but ongoing closure of schools, bars, airport and borders. School closures affect over 1,370,000 pupils.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200514103210/https://reliefweb.int/report/central-african-republic/unicef-central-african-republic-covid-19-situation-report-no-1-1-15    26 March 2020  Guidelines set forth by the government to contain the coronavirus range from systematic checks at border entry points and the self-isolation of passengers from countries at risk to mass communication initiatives and the prohibition of mass gatherings and movements.     Reinforcement measures were announced by the Head of State Faustin-Archange Touadera thereafter: limiting air traffic operations at the M’poko International Airport to a few commercial flights, humanitarian flights, cargo flights, aircrafts in difficulty and for technical stopovers without disembarkation; restrictions on the operation of educational establishments, places of recreation conducting mourning and marriage ceremonies; movement restrictions from Bangui to the provinces.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200514185240/https://peacekeeping.un.org/en/covid-19-cases-grow-car-minusca-supports-government-urgent-response-to-halt-virus-spread    17 April 2020  The MINUSCA Rwanda Contingent has donated a COVID-19 screening device to the Central African Republic (CAR). The machine will accelerate testing of suspected cases of infection as the number of confirmed coronavirus cases in the country reached 94 over the past few days.  https://www.africanews.com/2020/05/09/coronavirus-rwanda-donates-covid-19-testing-device-to-central-african-republic-car-by-maria-kabatanya//    23 April 2020   The World Bank approved a grant of $7.5 million from the International Development Association (IDA)* to help the Central African Republic respond to the threat posed by the Coronavirus outbreak and strengthen national systems for public health preparedness.    The COVID-19 Preparedness and Response Project will provide immediate support to the Central African Republic to prevent the spread of COVID-19 through containment strategies and by strengthening the public health emergency response for a potential outbreak. The project will bring in essential medical supplies and drugs, testing kits, personal protective equipment for frontline health workers, and water and hygiene supplies for the population.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200514105511/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/04/23/the-central-african-republic-to-strengthen-preparedness-and-response-to-coronavirus
notes_C7: "Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No"    https://web.archive.org/web/20201026125315/https://cf.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: "After almost seven months, pupils across the Central African Republic started to return to the classrooms on 19 October 2020 for the beginning of the school year 2020-2021. Schools were closed countrywide at the end of March as a measure to contain the spread of Covid-19. Some classes resumed in July and continued through to September, but only the three levels in an examination year, allowing pupils to proceed to the next class. Meanwhile, the children in the other nine levels without a year-end exam remained at home."    ===   While there has been an effort to maintain hygiene standards, it has proven very difficult in the usually very crowded classrooms. I am therefore coding this as "0" rather than "1G" as I believe it reflects the situation on the ground more closely.   I am also providing a source, describing the difficulties in maintaining the best hygiene standards:"The humanitarian community has also been supporting the Ministry of Education to prepare a safe return to school in the wake of Covid-19. Funds from the Global Partnership for Education, managed by UNICEF in the Central African Republic, allowed the purchase of hand washing facilities, soaps and similar items that are distributed to schools across the country. Humanitarian actors have also purchased facial masks for teachers and pupils. The Education Cluster has been supporting the Ministry of Education in elaborating a protocol, defining the hygiene standards at school in the context of the pandemic.    However, despite great efforts, schools in the Central African Republic are likely not in a position to respond effectively to the requirements of the pandemic. In the current context, where many schools are dilapidated and where one teacher looks on average after 113 children, respecting physical distance during classes is naturally difficult, to say the least. Respecting Covid-19 barrier measures would imply the construction of hundreds of new classrooms and the recruitment and training of thousands of teachers."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201123185702/https://reports.unocha.org/en/country/car/card/3uAzeWsox8/
notes_H6: while there is mention of a mandate, there is no evidence of enforcement  "social distancing measures, including the use of protective facemasks, is compulsory in all public spaces and public transportation, though this measure is not strictly enforced."  best site I could find in English is an aggregation site that references others https://archive.vn/BjQJc
notes_E2: this appears to show some income support, so captured but marked as none since no specific "debt relief" captured https://web.archive.org/web/20210112222155/https://projectsportal.afdb.org/dataportal/VTopCountry/show/CF
notes_E1: No policy update available
notes_C3: The Central African Republic U.K travel advice has removed information pertaining to large gatherings, perhaps indicating that they are no longer banned. I cannot find further evidence supporting this, but I have changed the coding to reflect this.  https://web.archive.org/web/20201026125053/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/central-african-republic/coronavirus

name: Canada
notes_H1: Still current     http://web.archive.org/web/20200907161916/https://www.canada.ca/en/public-health/services/diseases/coronavirus-disease-covid-19.html
notes_H3: On 6 November, Alberta Health focusses contact tracing on positive test cases who might have links to 3 priority settings -- schools, health care facilities, long-term care homes -- until contact tracing backlog cleared. See CAN_AB note for 6 November.
notes_H2: Date of extended testing also unknown, however, while not all were tested, the policy was extended with the addition of "assessment centres" which are meant for all those showing symptoms  Sources: https://web.archive.org/web/20200618102555/https://montrealgazette.com/news/local-news/quebec-ramps-up-covid-19-testing-with-goal-to-do-12000-a-day/
notes_C7: Nunavut restricts travel into province for non residents https://web.archive.org/web/20200415133437/https://www.gov.nu.ca/sites/default/files/order_re_travel_to_nunavut_final_v5signed.pdf
notes_C1: Effective 11 January, the first day of winter term class at most province of Ontario universities and colleges, post-secondary institutions move all classes online (with limited exceptions for small medical school applied sessions, etc.) in anticipation of the the provincial government’s signalled-well-in-advance decision to raise Ontario’s covid-19 alert status to the emergency level effective 14 January. Elementary and secondary schools had moved online when classes resumed on 4 January. With all education levels now online in Ontario, Canada’s most populous province, national code for Canada moved to 3T. See government of Ontario website archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210114204552/https://www.ontario.ca/page/covid-19-provincewide-shutdown  ***Note edited to reflect that the closing of this univeristy is at the discretion of the university rather than due to government policy. Therefore, it is not reflected in the coding; however, useful to understand the context for Canadian school closures. https://web.archive.org/web/20210109022315/https://www.uwo.ca/coronavirus/presidents-updates/
notes_H6: Based on province, e.g. Calgary: "Citing the rising numbers of coronavirus cases, the City of Calgary says it will make masks mandatory in all indoor public spaces starting Aug. 1."
notes_E2: "The Government, through Canada Mortgage and Housing Corporation (CMHC), is providing increased flexibility for homeowners facing financial difficulties to defer mortgage payments on homeowner CMHC-insured mortgage loans. CMHC will permit lenders to allow payment deferral beginning immediately."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200514161137/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/news/2020/03/canadas-covid-19-economic-response-plan-support-for-canadians-and-businesses.html    http://web.archive.org/web/20200514161242/https://www.cmhc-schl.gc.ca/en/finance-and-investing/mortgage-loan-insurance/the-resource/covid19-understanding-mortgage-payment-deferral
notes_E1: The Canada Emergency Wage Subsidy (CEWS) supports employers that are hardest hit by the pandemic, and protect the jobs Canadians depend on. The subsidy generally covers 75% of an employee's wages – up to $847 per week - for employers of all sizes and across all sectors who have suffered a drop in gross revenues of at least 15% in March, and 30% in April and May. The program will be in place for a 12-week period, from March 15 to June 6, 2020.  Also, the Canadian government will provide a taxable benefit of $2,000 every 4 weeks for up to 16 weeks to eligible workers who have lost their income due to COVID-19 under the Canadian Emergency Response Benefit.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200318220215/https://www.canada.ca/en/department-finance/economic-response-plan.html Then go to businesses
notes_C3: Alberta and BC both direct events over 250 people to be cancelled  https://web.archive.org/web/20200523183913/https://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/edmonton/alberta-covid-coronavirus-1.5496924
notes_C6: Effective 9 January, the government of Quebec imposed a province-wide curfew in place between 8pm and 5am. Being out during those hours is prohibited without a specifically exempted reason -- e.g., travelling to and from essential work, owners walking a dog within a 1 km radius of home. Curfew rules will be in place until 8 Feburary at least. See government of Quebec website, archived:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210112081748/https://www.quebec.ca/premier-ministre/actualites/detail/le-premier-ministre-francois-legault-annonce-de-nouvelles-mesures-sanitaires-pour-controler-la-deuxi/
notes_C8: Borders shut to all foreign nationals (except Americans on essential travel and Canadians returning home) https://www.canada.ca/en/transport-canada/news/2020/03/new-measures-for-covid-19-response.html Old unarchived link (that doesn't exist any more!): https://www.canada.ca/en/transport-canada/news/2020/03/new-measures-for-covid-19-response.html
notes_C2: Beginning November 18th for a 2 week period in Nunavut, all non-essential services, business and organisations will be required to close and wherever possible, switch to work from home.  All recreation facilities will be closed, all restaurants become take-out only, and bars will be closed. All personal services such as hairstylists and masseuses must close.   All health centres and the Qikiqtani General Hospital are closed except for emergency services.   https://web.archive.org/web/20201121180913/https://www.gov.nu.ca/health/news/nunavut-moves-territory-wide-covid-19-restrictions
notes_C4: Every province/territory has sub-regional restrictions in place on gatherings. A large majority fall within <10 people.  Limits in # of people gathering by province:  Quebec: 2 Ontario: 5 Manitoba, Saskatchewan, Newfoundland and Labrador and Yukon: <10 Northwest Territories, Prince Edward Island and Nunavut: 0 / no gatherings Alberta:15 British Columbia: 50  See:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200618073657/https://nationalpost.com/news/covid-19-time-for-feds-to-take-the-helm-on-social-distancing-measures-experts-say
notes_H7: On 20 January 2021, Indigenous Services Canada announced: “The rollout of the vaccines to many First Nations, Inuit, and Métis communities has started. Vaccine administration continues within communities, thanks to the commitment of Indigenous leadership and health experts, and federal, provincial, Indigenous collaboration, including on logistics and data sharing. To date vaccination has begun in 169 communities for First Nations or Inuit in all provinces and territories except Nova Scotia and PEI.” Covid vaccinations (Pfizer and Moderna) in Canada are being administered to 3 groups -- A. key workers (front-line health sector), B. clinically vulnerable groups (remote indigenous communities and federal prisoners at risk due to age or other health problems), C. elderly groups (residents of long-term care facilities and retirement homes). See Government of Canada and Globe and Mail newspaper websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126020941/https://www.canada.ca/en/indigenous-services-canada/news/2021/01/government-of-canada-covid-19-update-for-indigenous-peoples-and-communities1.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210126024649/https://www.theglobeandmail.com/politics/article-older-at-risk-federal-inmates-to-receive-shot-sparking-criticism-from/
notes_C5: Effective 6 January, the Office of Premier Blaine Higgs announced that “the entire province of New Brunswick will move to the Orange level... Public Health recommended the move due to the doubling of cases in less than six days … as well as reports of situations where some individuals were not complying with public health measures.” To comply with orange alert rules requiring 1m distancing on public transit, city transit services reduced bus seating capacity to 50% or 15-20 passengers on each bus.     See New Brunswick government websites, archived:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110192430/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/news/news_release.2021.01.0007.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110200130/https://www2.gnb.ca/content/gnb/en/corporate/promo/covid-19/recovery.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110205043/https://www.saintjohn.ca/news-and-service-updates/saint-john-transit-seating-capacity-reduced-by-covid-19-orange-phase  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110203956/https://www.fredericton.ca/en/transit

name: Switzerland
notes_H1: "Protect yourself and others" campaign started. https://web.archive.org/web/20200304163343/https://foph-coronavirus.ch/
notes_H3: Contact tracing is in the responsibility of the 26 cantons, making it difficult to assess the exact situation.    In terms of policy, it seems that all cantons continued, resumed or set up contact tracing as of 11 May 2020.  See below for a list of references to the cantons for which explicit documentation was found.  Therefore as of 11 May 2020, H2=2.    HOWEVER:   -the capacities are not always sufficient and information on this is documented in later entries  -there is no strong central coordination (the cantons do their own thing)  -although all cantons see it as their duty to implement contact tracing the wording at the federal level only talks about a "recommendation" as in:   "Contact tracing is recommended for all people with laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 or for hospitalized people with probable COVID-19. The responsible cantonal agency identifies the close contacts and contacts them."  (see http://web.archive.org/web/20200530165857/https://www.bag.admin.ch/bag/de/home/krankheiten/ausbrueche-epidemien-pandemien/aktuelle-ausbrueche-epidemien/novel-cov/information-fuer-die-aerzteschaft/contact-tracing.html)    Despite these restrictions, H2=2 seems to reflect the policy of the cantons best.    DETAILS ON 17/26 CANTONS  (Canton, start/resumption of contact tracing, source of information)    Zürich	11.05.20	http://web.archive.org/web/20200807072737/https://www.toponline.ch/news/zuerich/detail/news/contact-tracing-im-kanton-zuerich-wird-ausgebaut-00133958/    Luzern	04.05.20	http://web.archive.org/web/20200530083906/https://www.luzernerzeitung.ch/zentralschweiz/luzern/contact-tracing-ist-im-kanton-luzern-gut-angelaufen-ld.1220280
