name: Romania
notes_H1: Starting on 25/02/2020, an online information campaign was launched on the official Government of Romania Facebook page on the "Prevention and limitation of eventual infection with coronavirus". New, updated information has since been provided daily on the facebook page (https://web.archive.org/web/20200812130651/https://www.facebook.com/guv.ro)  On the 24/02/2020, this campaign was announced: "The information campaign of the population regarding the infection with COVID-19 will be extended, as well as the individual and collective prevention measures which should be taken and a daily newscast will be drafted regarding the development at international level and possible additional measures taken by the Romanian authorities" (https://web.archive.org/web/20200812130808/https://www.nineoclock.ro/2020/02/24/pm-designate-orban-urges-romanians-to-learn-about-coronavirus-from-official-sources-only/)
notes_H3: An official document regarding contact tracing and testing of contacts of COVID-19 confirmed patient was released by National Center for Surveillance and Control of Transmissible Diseases on 23rd of July 2020. On 28th of October, the Ministry of Health published updated the flow of information used in reporting SARS CoV-2 virus infection data.  According to this document, the Directorates of Public Health (DSP) have the obligation to identify and confirm, following the epidemiological investigation, direct contacts of each person tested positive.   Link: https://archive.fo/thRdi and https://archive.fo/FUhtr
notes_H2: 1. Symptomatic persons, including medical staff according to the case definition;   2. Symptomatic close contacts of confirmed cases;   3. Asymptomatic patients before the transplant procedure and donors of hematopoietic organs, tissues and stem cells before donation; patients with transplants of hematopoietic organs, tissues and stem cells undergoing immunosuppressive therapy, before each hospitalization during the post-transplant monitoring period - 2 tests at 24-hour intervals;   4. Asymptomatic patients with immunosuppression in the context of the disease or drug-induced hospitalization - 2 tests at 24-hour intervals;   5. Asymptomatic cancer patients undergoing chemotherapy and / or radiotherapy - twice a month;   6. Asymptomatic cancer patients before surgery or invasive interventions;   7. Symptomatic haemodialysis patients;   8. Asymptomatic haemodialysis patients contacts with a confirmed case, 2 tests at 6-7 days interval between them; during this period they will be dialyzed in separate sessions from the rest of the patients;   9. Symptomatic institutionalized individuals;   10. Asymptomatic pregnant women in quarantine/home isolation or close contact with a confirmed case;   11. Staff of residential centres/long-term care facilities – twice a month;   12. Asymptomatic healthcare personnel who have been in direct contact with a confirmed case, in the 6th or 7th day since the last contact.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200608103644/https://www.cnscbt.ro/index.php/1697-definitii-de-caz-si-algoritm-de-testare-pentru-covid-19-actualizare-28-04-2020-1/file
notes_C7: According to the Decision 35/10.02.2021, the alert status on the Romanian territory is extended. It is in place a ban for traffic persons outside the home between 23:00 and 5:00 (exception for travel in professional interest, for medical assistance). Additionally, the Ministry of Interior published the list of quarantined localities.  Link: Link: https://archive.fo/4mnCH and https://archive.fo/wip/a09tG
notes_C1: Romania began to reopen schools on 8 February, three months after the Government closed schools throughout the country to limit the spread of the COVID-19 pandemic.    There are 3 scenarios for reopening schools based on the epidemiological situation in each locality:    The green scenario, which applies to towns with low incidence rates of COVID-19, allows all children to return to school.    The yellow scenario, which applies to cities with moderate incidence rates, only kindergarten children and primary school (I-IV grades) pupils return to school, plus those in the eighth and twelfth grades, who have to prepare for the national exams.    The red scenario, which applies in localities with incidence rates of over 3 per 1,000 inhabitants (over a 14-day period), only kindergarten and primary school children return to school.    Students who can’t return to school, either due to the yellow or red scenarios, will continue online courses, which have been going on for most of the first semester.    Currently, the cumulative incidence of cases in the last 14 days is over 3 per 1,000 occupants in Timis and Maramures counties, therefore, these counties are in the red scenario.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211716/https://www.romaniajournal.ro/society-people/education/physical-classes-in-schools-resumed-as-of-february-8/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211543/https://www.edu.ro/sites/default/files/ordin%20comun%20nr.%203.235_93_4.02.2021.pdf    https://archive.fo/85fHU
notes_H6: According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 (extended through Decision 58/10.12.2020) of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces, regardless the value of the cumulative incidence rate of cases in the last 14 days (as it previously of this decision was).   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf, https://web.archive.org/web/20201212161456/https://www.gov.ro/fisiere/pagini_fisiere/Hotarare_CNSU_nr._58_din_10.12.2020.pdf and https://archive.fo/4mnCH
notes_E2: On 1 January 2021, Emergency Ordinance No. 227 went into effect.    The bank's clients, individuals with ongoing loans, whose income was directly or indirectly affected by the COVID-19 pandemic, can benefit from the facility to suspend the payment of installments according to GEO 37/2020 as amended by GEO 227/2020 .    The total period of suspension of payment obligations for a loan is a maximum of 9 months and includes: the periods of suspension requested and granted until 15 June 2020 based on GEO 37/2020, the periods of suspension granted based on a private moratorium and the periods of suspension requested after the entry into force of GEO 227/2020.    Under these conditions, only clients who have not already benefited from the maximum deferral period for payment based on the public moratorium established by GEO 37/2020 and / or based on a private moratorium are eligible.       In order to benefit from the suspension of payments according to GEO 37/2020 as amended by GEO 227/2020, the following criteria must be met:    Individual’s income and / or family income has been affected by the situation generated by the COVID-19 pandemic compared to the level registered before the declaration of the state of emergency and is are unable to honor the payment obligations related to the credit.     15 March is the application deadline, inclusive.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220061111/http://legislatie.just.ro/Public/DetaliiDocument/235875    https://web.archive.org/web/20200507141027/https://www.raiffeisen.ro/persoane-fizice/in-sprijinul-tau/asistenta/suspendare-rate-credite/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210220062628/https://www.unicredit.ro/ro/persoane-fizice/Diverse/covid-19.html
notes_E1: A Government Emergency Ordinance (GEO 30/2020) has been published, outlining social protection measures during the state of emergency due to COVID-19. The measures introduced by GEO 30/2020 come into force on 21 March 2020.  'The Labor Code provides that employers can decide unilaterally to suspend individual employment agreements of their employees and place the employees in technical unemployment. The employer is required to ensure from its own funds the payment of a minimum allowance of 75% of the employee’s base salary. However, if the employers meet one of the following criteria, during the state of emergency, the technical unemployment allowance can be supported by the Unemployment Insurance Budget up to the limit of 75% of the average gross salary provided for under the law for the social insurance budget for 2020'.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200502180616/https://home.kpmg/ro/en/home/insights/2020/03/social-protection-measures-during-the-state-of-emergency.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20200812125709/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, the meetings on public holidays, public and/or private parties in closed and/or open spaces are prohibited.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf
notes_C6: Throughout Romania, it is forbidden for people to be outside the home between 23.00 - 05.00, with the following exceptions:    Travel in the professional interest, including between home / household and the place / places where the professional activity takes place and back.    Travel for medical care that cannot be postponed or performed remotely, as well as for the purchase of medicines.    Travel outside the locality of persons who are in transit or make journeys whose time interval overlaps with the prohibition period such as those made by plane, train, coach or other means of passenger transport and which can be proved by ticket or any another way to pay for the trip.    Travel for justified reasons, such as caring for / accompanying the child, assisting the elderly, sick or disabled or the death of a family member.    In order to justify moving away from home during this period, citizens must have on them the declaration on their own responsibility, the certificate from the employer or the service card (the last two can only be used to justify moving for professional purposes).    https://web.archive.org/web/20210219211825/https://stirioficiale.ro/conduita
notes_C8: There are screening procedures implemented at the “Henri Coanda” International Airport (three thermal scanners and a joint action plan with the Border Police and the Public Health Directorate to collect questionnaires from travelers arriving in the country and to distribute information about local measures and restrictions) The National Institute of Public Health published a new list of states with high epidemiological risk. The decisions no.6/04.02.2021 and 9/11.02.2021 of National Committee for Emergency Situations contain the required conditions for the passengers coming in Romania from countries with high epidemiological risk.   Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20210226145023/http://www.cnscbt.ro/index.php/liste-zone-afectate-covid-19, https://web.archive.org/web/20210228162247/https://stirioficiale.ro/hotarari/hotararea-nr-9-din-11-02-2021-cnsu and https://web.archive.org/web/20210219215935/https://ro.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, fairs, mixed, flying and flea markets will be forbidden. For the economic operators having activities in closed and/or open spaces, (public or private) to organize their activity only between 05:00 and 21:00. According to the Decision 56/4.12.2020, it is proposed to resume the activity of agri-food markets organized in closed spaces. Outdoor cafes and clubs are closed between 11 PM and 6 AM.  Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20201120195835/https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf and https://archive.fo/wip/cz2hH
notes_C4: Social events such as weddings and funerals are limited to 10 guests.  Link: https://archive.fo/kYCaw
notes_H7: Second stage of the vaccination campaign started on 15th of January and is aimed at people over 65 age, people with chronic diseases (regardless of age) and key staff working in key areas. The coordinator of the National Committee for the Planning of COVID-19 Vaccination in Romania, announced how the appointments of people over 65 years of age and those with chronic diseases can be made. (Pfizer-BioNTech and Moderna vaccines are used).  Link: https://archive.fo/wip/IzHsa and https://archive.fo/wip/qeZ7F
notes_C5: According to the Decision 52/5.11.2020 of The National Emergency Committee, it is in place the obligation to wear a protective mask, to cover the nose and mouth, for all persons who have reached the age of 5, in all open and closed public spaces. Also, to avoid the congestion of public transport, it is proposed to all public institutions and all economic operators to organize work schedule (where telework is not possible) into at least two groups to start/finish the activity at a difference of at least two hours.  Link: https://s.iw.ro/gateway/g/ZmlsZVNvdXJjZT1odHRwJTNBJTJGJTJG/c3RvcmFnZTA2dHJhbnNjb2Rlci5yY3Mt/cmRzLnJvJTJGc3RvcmFnZSUyRjIwMjAl/MkYxMSUyRjA2JTJGMTI0ODQ3NV8xMjQ4/NDc1X0hvdGFyYXJlLUNOU1UtNTItZGlu/LTA1XzExXzIwMjAtdjE5LTEucGRmJmhh/c2g9NjkxN2E0NDIwOTQ4MGQ1NjJiYzMxZmNjYjczZjY2NjI=.pdf

name: Russia
notes_H1: Prime Minister announces a plan to roll out a public information campaign about the coronavirus progression in the near future. (http://web.archive.org/web/20200505222301/https://www.kommersant.ru/doc/4290524)
notes_H3: The government issued a decree in November 2020 regarding contact people. The government recommends contacts stay isolated and get tested only when contacts have symptoms. There is no manual contact tracing in Russia.   https://archive.vn/rPKzp
notes_H2: Testing is widely available in Russia, both through government healthcare providers and private clinics.  Testing is free at government healthcare providers for those suspected of having coronavirus.  Link: https://archive.vn/4ShjR
notes_C7: Are there restrictions on intercity or interstate travel? No  Link: https://archive.vn/MxaXR
notes_C1: Schools and universities are back to off-line learning nation-wide.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308121653/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H6: The code should be changed to 2G.  On October 28th, the government of the Russian Federation reinstated a requirement to wear masks in crowded public areas, including public transportation, taxis, parking lots, and elevators. This order applies to the entire country.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210221214744/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_E2: Due to the coronavirus in 2020, various exemptions were introduced for Russian citizens, including a ban on penalty for communal debts and a moratorium on the verification of metering devices. From January 2021, all these exemptions for households are lifted.   Link: https://archive.vn/3YHi3
notes_E1: According to the Decree ? 2393 from 31 December 2020, the government extended the maximum amount of unemployment benefits until the end of 2021 due to COVID-19. The maximum allowance will remain at 12,130 rubles. In the first three months, an unemployed citizen will be paid 75 percent of lost salary, and the second three months – 60 percent of lost salary.   It should be mentioned that in March 2020 the maximum amount of unemployment benefits was increased from 8,000 rubles to 12,130 rubles. Initially, this was a temporary government measure to support unemployed citizens during COVID-19. However, at the end of 2020, the government decided to keep the maximum allowance in 2021 at the same level as before.   Links: https://archive.vn/NOmKP https://archive.vn/w7MzJ https://archive.vn/FLNJD
notes_C3: The U.S embassy on Russia indicates "some jurisdictions place limitations on large gatherings and mass events". However, no specific policies were found associated with this indicator.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200831224047/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: Moscow and Saint Petersburg have lifted a number of restrictions. The government recommends citizens stay at home. But there is no curfew in place across the country.   Links: https://archive.vn/MxaXR https://archive.vn/JZYIB
notes_C8: From at least 17 November, the Government of the Russian Federation banned the entry of foreign nationals, including American citizens, with a few exceptions.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201122205355/https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Moscow and Saint Petersburg have lifted a number of restrictions. Currently, in Saint Petersburg theaters, museums, and other cultural venues may not exceed the 50-percent capacity. Earlier, the limit was 25 percent.   Links: https://archive.vn/H4TXW https://archive.vn/SOe9e https://archive.vn/JZYIB
notes_C4: Some jurisdictions place limitations on large gatherings and mass events. See: https://ru.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ [accessed 12th October 2020, web archive unavailable, webpage last updated 6th October 2020]
notes_H7: From 18 January 2021, Russia launched a mass vaccination policy for free. Everyone 18+can receive a vaccine on a voluntary basis. It should be mentioned that during December only elderly people, medical workers, and people with chronic diseases had an opportunity to receive vaccines. Now, there are no such restrictions. Since the vaccination on a voluntary basis and the number of people to get vaccinated only increasing.      Links: https://archive.vn/kmTXE https://archive.vn/jkeWX https://archive.vn/qTPC4 https://archive.vn/0s2lb
notes_C5: No measures found relative to closing transports on the RF's coronavirus official website nor in the news, other than masks are mandatory in some cities.

name: Rwanda
notes_H1: The Rwandan government hastened safety measures against coronavirus and were consistent in reminding Rwanda citizens to be more vigilant on preventing novel coronavirus.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200430191424/https://www.afro.who.int/news/rwanda-hastens-safety-measures-against-novel-coronavirus   https://web.archive.org/web/20200430185258/https://www.primature.gov.rw/index.php?id=40  https://web.archive.org/web/20201120191729/https://www.newvision.co.ug/news/1516513/coronavirus-rwanda-closes-churches-schools
notes_H3: Rwanda confirmed its first case of coronavirus, an Indian citizen who arrived in the East African nation from Mumbai on March 8, according to the Health Ministry. Since then the World Health Organisation (WHO) has confirmed that the tracing of all contacts in Rwanda has been conducted for further management.       https://web.archive.org/web/20200430194341/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-rwanda/rwanda-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus-health-ministry-idUKKBN2110G0     https://web.archive.org/web/20200430194919/https://www.afro.who.int/countries/842/news?page=3
notes_H2: Testing available at accredited test centers (for a charge)    https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_C7: ?Travel between Kigali and other provinces and districts is not permitted, except for essential services and tourism (tourists must possess a negative COVID-19 test result).  Travelers, including drivers, traveling to tourism entities within Kigali and other provinces and districts are required to complete and submit movement requests through the Tourism Movement Facilitation Form found here. Travelers are also required to send copies of negative COVID-19 test results to visitrwanda@rbd.rwat least 24 hours prior to the trip.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210315130931/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_C1: From 23-Feb-21 - All schools (public and private), including universities, will resume.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Masks are required in public.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_E2: 18/03 announced  National Bank of Rwanda announced easing of loan repayment conditions for borrowers affected by the Covid-19: banks are exceptionally allowed to restructure outstanding loans of borrowers temporarily facing cash flow challenges due to Covid-19: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507084813/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/east-africa/2020/03/23/central-bank-of-rwanda-takes-measures-to-mitigate-the-economic-impact-of-covid-19/    The Rwandan Ministry of Finance and Economic Planning has announced a series of tax exemptions as part of efforts to support different sectors of the economy to recover from the effects of COVID 19 pandemic. Pay As You Earn (PAYE) will be waived for a period of six months from April to September for teachers in private schools earning up to 150,000 Rwandan francs net salary (about 161 U.S. dollars), a statement issued by the ministry said. The waiver will also apply for a period of three months from April to June for employees of companies operating in the tourism and hotel sector who earn up to 150,000 Rwandan francs net salary, the statement said. PAYE waiver lasts till September for teachers, and till June for everyone else. The government also exempted masks made in Rwanda to prevent COVID-19 spread from paying Value Added Tax (VAT).  https://web.archive.org/web/20200825035927/http://www.xinhuanet.com/english/2020-05/10/c_139045597.htm
notes_E1: Full IMF statement: As of November 4, 2020 "Tax deferral and relief measures include the following: (i) suspension of down payments on outstanding tax for amicable settlement, (ii)softening of enforcement for tax arrears collection, (iii) extension of the deadline for filing and paying CIT, (iv) fast-tracking of VAT refunds to SMEs, (v) CIT and PIT payments based on current year transactions, (vi) PIT exemption for private school teachers and tourism and hotel employees earning less than RWF 150,000/month, and (vi) VAT exemption for locally produced masks."    Main impact on indicator is cash transfers to casual workers  https://web.archive.org/web/20200904183810/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  PIT exemption for private school teachers and tourism and hotel employees earning less than RWF 150,000/month - as per the update on 10th Sept 2020  https://web.archive.org/web/20200914124848/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: Religious gatherings limited to max. 30% capacity. Restaurants, cafes and essential business to operate with max. 30% capacity/occupancy, markets and malls with up to 50% capacity.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_C6: Stay-at-home orders have been eased, although a night-time curfew remains in effect.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210210002042/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/rwanda-eases-covid-19-lockdown-in-capital/2137274
notes_C8: Everyone will be tested on arrival and must quarantine in a designated hotel for 24 hours pending the result. If staying longer than seven days, thereafter seven days quarantine at home.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210218085810/https://www.wko.at/service/aussenwirtschaft/coronavirus-situation-in-kosovo.html
notes_C2: Business must close by 18:00. Restaurants can offer take away service until 20:00.      https://web.archive.org/web/20210304095728/https://rw.usembassy.gov/health-alert-covid-19-information/
notes_C4: All social gatherings and events including religious weddings ceremonies, receptions, meetings and conferences are prohibited.  Funeral gatherings should not exceed 15 persons. Bars, places of worship, and gaming activities are all closed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210202141756/https://www.gov.rw/fileadmin/user_upload/gov_user_upload/Publications/Cabinet_Resolutions/Statement_on_Cabinet_Resolutions_of_18_January_2021.pdf
notes_H7: A - Key workers via Covax  & C - Elderly groups - it doesn't say which type.   The vaccination is expected to be done in phases. In the first phase, the vaccine will go to front-line workers in healthcare including but not limited to those working in treatment centres and Intensive Care Units (ICUs). This phase will also see the vaccination of people above 65 and those whose immunity is weak and is likely to easily be compromised like those with cancer, diabetes, HIV and other serious diseases.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210223001542/https://www.pmnewsnigeria.com/2021/02/15/rwanda-begins-covid-19-vaccination-for-health-workers-others/   https://web.archive.org/web/20210128052530/https://www.newtimes.co.rw/news/unpacking-rwanda-plan-distribute-covid-19-vaccine
notes_C5: It appears that restrictions on public transport have been eased.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210210002042/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/rwanda-eases-covid-19-lockdown-in-capital/2137274

name: Saudi Arabia
notes_H1: The Ministry of Health conducts campaigns that target citizens and residents (in Arabic, English, Hindy, Tagalog, among others) reporting the number of cases and recommending people how to take preventative measures. https://web.archive.org/web/20200608033137/https://twitter.com/SaudiMOH/status/1244341052196163585
notes_H3: In February, the Saudi Center for Disease Prevention and control released a comprehensive set of Coronavirus Health Guidelines. The guidelines instruct the public health team or rapid response team to conduct a number of measures for a patient that has the virus, including filling out a contact tracing form (Appendix  3 in the guidelines) https://www.moh.gov.sa/CCC/healthp/regulations/Documents/Coronavirus%20Disease%202019%20Guidelines%20v1.1..pdf
notes_H2: "The ministry highlighted that the new phase will not include COVID-19 examination inside houses or by visiting residences. Instead, the ministry will provide different outlets and options to conduct the tests. It will establish drive-through centers for testing people inside their cars in several cities while also offering testing services at primary health care centers, and allow citizens and residents to book appointments to collect their own test samples through an online application."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200608034049/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1677726/saudi-arabia
notes_C7: "There are currently no curfew or movement restrictions in effect within the country (...)"    Sources: http://web.archive.org/web/20200819124650/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: The Ministry of Education determined schools and universities would close to stop the spread of the virus. https://web.archive.org/web/20200608023056/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1638606/saudi-arabia
notes_H6: On 30 May, face masks become mandatory in public places. Non-compliance is fined with up to SR1,000 ($266).     Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200831214012/https://www.arabnews.com/node/1686821/saudi-arabia
notes_E2: Eligible people (social insurance beneficiaries, orphans and the disabled) were waived from paying rent for 3 months. https://web.archive.org/web/20200414205607/http://saudigazette.com.sa/article/591775/SAUDI-ARABIA/Social-insurance-beneficiaries-orphans-and-disabled-exempted-from-paying-rent-for-3-months
notes_E1: Saudi Government has announced to pay 60% of the salaries of Saudi employees working in the Private sector for a period of three months with a ceiling of USD 2.39 billion. The Compensation will be paid in accordance with the conditions stipulated in the unemployment insurance system (SANID)  https://web.archive.org/web/20201221220947/https://home.kpmg/xx/en/home/insights/2020/04/saudi-arabia-government-and-institution-measures-in-response-to-covid.html
notes_C3: No mention of public events, but given that gatherings over 50 are still prohibited, I think this should still be coded as a 2G.  "Saudi Arabia has allowed social events — including wedding receptions and other celebrations — to be held from Thursday, with up to 50 people, ensuring guests must wear face masks and abide by the social distancing protocol."  Source  https://web.archive.org/web/20200729161532/https://gulfnews.com/world/gulf/saudi/saudi-arabia-allows-social-events-weddings-with-up-to-50-people-1.1593635688372
notes_C6: Cannot find any government guidance that recommends to people to stay at home, including the source used for the previous 1G coding.
notes_C8: The Saudi authorities require anyone who is travelling from a country where the new strain of COVID-19 has spread to spend at least 14 days outside the affected country before entering the Kingdom https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/saudi-arabia
notes_C2: Beginning March 7, the government has lifted the "the precautionary measures which had previously set to suspend all entertainment activities and events, closing cinemas and indoor entertainment centers as well as independent indoor games' venues, or those in restaurants and shopping centers and the like, gyms and sports centers, internal ordering services in restaurants and cafes and the like." Inspection campaigns for these places will be increased and reopened places must follow precautionary measures.   https://archive.ph/iNqqX
notes_C4: With Hajj over, the guidelines are still generally at limits of 50 people to a social gathering.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200810132047/https://sa.usembassy.gov/u-s-citizen-services/covid-19-information/

notes_H6: It seems that there are preventive measures outlined by the government as evident from the lack of adherence as cited by this article.     ""We observed that the majority of citizens and officials appear to have given up on wearing face masks and regular hand sanitization," the doctors said in a statement issued Friday evening, adding that "most public institutions, shopping, and medical centers are no longer providing handwashing facilities or sanitizers at entrances or within the buildings."  The doctors also expressed concern about public noncompliance with COVID-19 prevention measures amid laxity in enforcing coronavirus prevention measures across the country." name: Senegal
notes_H1: The president calls on religious authorities to support the government with adopted measures.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200518002240/http://www.sante.gouv.sn/Actualites/covid-19-les-decisions-de-son-execellence-monsieur-macky-sall-president-de-la-republique
notes_H2: "Individuals in Senegal may obtain COVID-19 testing at the following locations. The cost is FCFA 40,000 per test."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111200501/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: The motorways between the international airport and Thiès and between the airport and Mbour are closed between 8pm and 6am.    The Government of Senegal has advised that the airport will remain open and existing flight schedules will not change. People can still travel to the airport during curfew if they are passengers arriving and departing or the driver (no other people accompanying passengers are allowed). All of these people must carry a copy of their passport and plane ticket, which will allow for movement to the airport or to their accommodation. If you are arriving into Senegal at the airport in curfew hours, you should contact the person or taxi company you have arranged to collect you in advance to make sure they can still access the airport and have all the necessary paperwork.    There is currently no restriction on travel between regions, and authorisation is not needed to travel between regions. Internal flights have also restarted. Masks must be worn at all times in public areas and when travelling, including in a private car if there are two or more people in the car.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210125055820/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
notes_C1: Schools reopened in Senegal on November 12th. Students are required to wear masks, and distancing is encouraged.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221221105/http://nouvelhorizon.sn/index.php/2020/11/12/le-fait-du-jour-rentree-des-classes-sous-le-signe-du-racket-des-ecoles-privees/    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221222443/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fsnmen%2Fposts%2F2906065296280444    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221222738/https://www.facebook.com/login/?next=https%3A%2F%2Fwww.facebook.com%2Fsnmen%2Fposts%2F2931551557065151
notes_H6: Masks must be worn in all public areas throughout Senegal, including in supermarkets, on public transport (which is still operating with reduced capacity), in taxis, and when on public streets.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
notes_E2: Previous note referred to this note    "One million households receive food aid (FCFA 69 billion) and utility payments for (for water and electricity) for poorer customers were suspended for a 2-month period (FCFA 18,5 billion)."    But this 2 month period has elapsed    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221143702/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: There is no mention of broad income support in the IMF Policy tracker.     "Social protection: One million households receive food aid (FCFA 69 billion) and utility payments for (for water and electricity) for poorer customers were suspended for a 2-month period (FCFA 18,5 billion)."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221143702/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19    There is evidence of payments to vulnerable/low-income groups, but not an income support program for all workers.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201221233937/http://nouvelhorizon.sn/index.php/2020/04/21/debut-des-paiements-des-bourses-de-securite-familiale-communique/
notes_C3: On December 10, the Government of Senegal re-affirmed its previous announcement regarding the mandatory wearing of masks in public places and in private places receiving the public, as well the ban on gatherings in theaters, bars, public beaches, and sports fields. However, restaurants, casinos, places of worship, private beaches and markets are permitted to operate while maintaining social distancing measures and facial coverings.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201221225739/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C6: The president issued a state of emergency with a partial curfew from 21h to 6h in the regions of Dakar and Thies, beginning Jan 6, 2021 at 21h.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210111193150/http://nouvelhorizon.sn/index.php/2021/01/05/urgent-covid19-etat-durgence-a-dakar-et-thies/    Protests erupted in the regions. "A protester named Babacar Seck said the curfew was inconsistent with what was happening during the day. 'Street markets remained open and people were still packed in public transport,' he said."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210111200126/https://www.arise.tv/violence-erupts-in-senegal-as-citizens-protest-new-covid-19-measures/
notes_C8: •  All travelers to Senegal over the age of two years must present an original COVID-19 test certificate showing a negative result. The test must occur within five days of entry into Senegal. The results must be from a PCR test (not a rapid test) and be issued by a laboratory approved for such testing or a recognized international health organization.  Travelers transiting Senegal must also show such proof if they will be present in Senegal more than 24 hours or wish to exit the airport.   •  Verification of testing compliance will be undertaken by the airline prior to departure.  Passengers without a negative COVID-19 test may not be permitted to board.   •  All travellers to Senegal may also be required to complete a passenger location form for public health officials, in accordance with recommendations from the International Civil Aviation Organization.  The form will be collected on arrival. The form is available for preview and download here.   •  The Government of Senegal has implemented restrictions that impact entry into Senegal for certain foreign nationals.  https://web.archive.org/save/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: On 8 January, the Interior Minister announced that for the Dakar and Thiès regions all public gatherings are prohibited including at hotels, bars, beaches, sports grounds, theatres and public spaces. Consequently, many bars and other public venues are closing. Religious sites are open. Restrictions are changing rapidly; you should follow instructions given by the authorities.  Restaurants, casinos, places of worship, private beaches and markets are permitted to operate while maintaining social distancing measures and facial coverings.     https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/senegal/coronavirus
notes_C4: Country-wide restrictions on "gatherings in public spaces" remains in effect.     Additionally, in the regions of Dakar and Thies, private meetings including baptisms, weddings, receptions and religious events are prohibited.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210111193453/https://www.msn.com/fr-xl/afrique-de-l-ouest/other/covid-19-manifestations-et-rassemblements-interdits-temporairement-%C3%A0-dakar-et-thi%C3%A8s/ar-BB1cz5Ln
notes_H7: Note: Senegal has received vaccines Sinopharm vaccines from China (also expects vaccines from COVAX and Russia potentially). See: https://www.africanews.com/2021/02/23/senegal-begins-covid-19-vaccination-with-doses-from-china-s-sinopharm// [web archive unavailable]  The Government of Senegal has launched an online platform for individuals who reside in Senegal to register their interest in receiving the COVID vaccine. https://web.archive.org/web/20210227221356/https://sn.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Also: Senegal's vaccination strategy is focused on two stages: The first will include health personnel, the elderly, those with co-morbidities. Stage two will involve the vaccination of an estimated 80% of the population, by the end of 2022. See https://www.weforum.org/agenda/2021/02/senegal-covid-response-macky-sall/ [web archive unavailable]

name: Singapore
notes_H1: https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/precautionary-measures-in-response-to-severe-pneumonia-cases-in-wuhan-china
notes_H3: In update to public, Singapore MOH lays out strategy once case is confirmed:"Once a case is confirmed, contact tracing will be initiated, and we will implement strict isolation, quarantine, and infection control and prevention measures to prevent further transmission." Since this is clear indication of a contract tracing policy in place, coded as start date; https://web.archive.org/web/20200527191250/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/moh-steps-up-precautionary-measures-in-response-to-increase-in-cases-of-novel-coronavirus-pneumonia-in-wuhan
notes_H2: "“As Singapore has made good progress to support a further resumption of activities, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce (MTF) will start Phase 3 of re-opening from 28 Dec 2020.  Update on pre-conditions for moving into Phase 3  To move into Phase 3, we needed:  (…) Sufficient testing capabilities for early detection and public health action: Singapore ramped up Polymerase Chain Reaction (PCR) test capacity significantly to be able to run over 50,000 tests a day. Antigen rapid tests were also introduced for larger and higher-risk events.”    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231155002/https://www.gov.sg/article/moving-into-phase-3-of-re-opening-on-28-dec-2020
notes_C7: From June 19, Singapore has entered Phase Two of its COVID19 policy, where most sectors of the economy and most schools have reopened and public transport is operating. In a small city-state like Singapore, this effectively means internal movement is no longer restricted.     https://archive.vn/qVq8N
notes_C1: "Students will return to school from June 2 over two phases as part of the easing of the coronavirus circuit breaker measures that are expected to end on June 1.    Here are some of the adjustments planned for schools and pre-schools that the Government announced on Tuesday (May 19).    1. Phase 1 of resuming school: First few weeks from June 2    For primary and secondary schools:  -Primary 6, Secondary 4 and Secondary 5 students will attend school on weekdays.    - The rest of the upper levels (Primary 4 and 5, or Secondary 3) will alternate weekly with the lower levels (Primary 1, 2, and 3, or Secondary 1 and 2) to be back in school for one week, then switch to home-based learning the next week.    For junior colleges (JCs) and Millennia Institute (MI):  - Up to half of the students will return to school. JCs and MI will prioritise JC2 and Pre-University 3 students, with some rotation of students from the other levels.    For special education (Sped) schools:  - Students' return will be staggered from June 2. All students will be back in school by June 8.    For institutes of higher learning (IHLs):  - Polytechnic students will return primarily for practical and laboratory sessions. Lessons and tutorials will remain online.  - Institute of Technical Education students will rotate weekly between online and on-campus lessons. They will return primarily for practical and lab sessions.    For pre-schools:  - Kindergarten 1 and Kindergarten 2 children may return from June 2.  - Nursery 1 and Nursery 2 children may return from June 8.  - Infant care and playgroup children may return from June 10.  - Early intervention centres to reopen in phases from June 2, starting with in-person intervention for children with higher needs."    Note: According to the codebook childcare is captured in C2 and hybrid teaching (in-class and online teaching), since schools are not fully closed, should be coded as 1G.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201207122250/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/schools-to-open-in-phases-from-june-2-after-covid-19-circuit-breaker-how-this-will-work
notes_H6: From April 14, masks became mandatory at all times once leaving the house. https://web.archive.org/web/20200902003543/https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/singapore/covid19-wearing-masks-compulsory-lawrence-wong-12640828
notes_E2: "The Act covers contracts for rentals in the industrial and commercial sectors, construction and supply contracts, as well as certain secured loan facilities granted by a bank or a finance company to small and medium-sized enterprises.  Contracts for events such as weddings or conferences, as well as in tourism, such as cruise and hotel bookings, are also covered."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201210010413/https://www.straitstimes.com/singapore/how-to-seek-contractual-relief-for-yourself-or-your-business-under-the-covid-19-temporary
notes_E1: On 26 May, the government announced the Fortitude Budget. The Job Support Scheme (JSS) will be extended for 1 more month to cover wages in August 2020. For firms that cannot resume operations immediately after the circuit breaker, the Government will continue to provide wage support at 75% until August 2020, or when they are allowed to re-open (whichever is earlier). There will also be increased support for some affected sectors (eg. aerospace sector, retail, marine and offshore) - an increase from the previous 25% to either 50% or 75%.    Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200712075233/https://www.gov.sg/article/a-summary-of-the-fortitude-budget-2020
notes_C3: Starting from 1 October 2020, STB will start accepting applications for Event Organisers and Event Venues to pilot MICE events of up to 5 zones of 50 attendees (250 pax) with attendees to be divided into cohorts of 20.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201021161056/https://www.imda.gov.sg/news-and-events/Media-Room/Media-Releases/2020/Advisories-on-COVID-19-Situation
notes_C6: People are encouraged to work from home wherever possible, and social distancing measures must be complied with, but there are no curfews or requirements in place.    https://archive.vn/qVq8N
notes_C8: http://web.archive.org/web/20210116174339/https://www.gov.sg/article/how-is-singapore-limiting-the-spread-of-covid-19
notes_C2: Quote: ""We are asking the various companies to put in place the various measures and they will start to prepare now...As soon as they are ready by 12 May, they can resume work," Minister of Trade and Industry Chan Chun Sing said at a virtual press conference on Sunday." "We will not be able to open some of the social entertainment outlets, but we are focused on our manufacturing capacities and production capabilities," he said.  http://web.archive.org/web/20210117171016/https://english.kyodonews.net/news/2020/05/bf158de5d991-singapore-to-ease-lockdown-let-businesses-reopen-from-may-12.html
notes_C4: ***Recoded from 2G to 4G; was previously coded in relation to public event size rather than private gatherings     See previous coding note:   "As Singapore has made good progress to support a further resumption of activities, the Multi-Ministry Taskforce (MTF) will start Phase 3 of re-opening from 28 Dec 2020. (…)    - Group size for gatherings will be increased from 5 to 8 persons: 	Up to 8 persons for social gatherings and household visitors at any point in time”  - Total of 10 persons for marriage soleminsations + up to 8 visitors allowed”  -worship services allowed up to 250 people    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231155002/https://www.gov.sg/article/moving-into-phase-3-of-re-opening-on-28-dec-2020
notes_H7: A; C   Policy update: "The first day of COVID-19 vaccination for our seniors aged 70 years old and above commenced on 27 January with two pilots at the Ang Mo Kio and Tanjong Pagar towns, which is home to a larger number of our elderly." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210130223217/https://www.moh.gov.sg/news-highlights/details/update-on-covid-19-vaccination-programme  ***updated to include properly archived link and groups

name: Sierra Leone
notes_H1: Since April 2, the government activated the Public Health Emergency Operations Center and developed a national COVID-19 preparedness plan, which focuses primarily on strengthening surveillance at the three official points of entry, improving case management, and conducting effective campaigns at the national, subnational and community levels. See: https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.worldbank.org/en/news/press-release/2020/04/02/sierra-leone-to-receive-75-million-for-covid-19-response
notes_H3: According to a UNICEF report in November 2020, community health workers (CHWs) have been engaged in contact tracing. Whilst there are no recent mentions of CHWs, it could be assumed that as long as SLE is still seeing active cases of COVID-19 and with the the state of emergency extended to at least March 2021, people will still be engaged in contact tracing. For the UNICEF report, please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210103115057/https://reliefweb.int/report/sierra-leone/unicef-sierra-leone-covid-19-situation-report-no-11-1-30-november-2020#main
notes_H2: “we have quickly isolated case number one. We have immediately and aggressively operationalised tracking and surveillance for all primary and secondary contacts (Ed.Note: that is every person Case# 1 may have come into contact with)."  "Those persons will be placed into mandatory quarantine and tested immediately starting today [Tuesday, March 31st]. From now on, I direct that health teams proactively seek out and compulsorily test all suspected cases.”   "When questioned by journalists about the level of testing, the Minister of Health Alpha Wurie revealed that health officials had been conducting tests only when patients are suspected with “signs and symptoms” and so far they have done 42 of those tests."  (https://web.archive.org/web/20200403200158/http://www.rfi.fr/en/international/20200331-no-lockdown-yet-as-sierra-leone-records-first-case-of-covid-19)
notes_C7: From 25 January, entry and exit from the Western Area - the territory corresponding to Freetown and its surroundings – are restricted.    Link: https://archive.vn/q8DpI
notes_C1: (Oct 5) Schools began reopening on October 5th, following the plan set out by the Ministry of Education in the months prior. In addition to opening, they have revamped the guidelines for how schools operate.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201013204135if_/https://www.facebook.com/Ministry-of-Basic-and-Senior-Secondary-Education-SL-1410711375879238/photos/pcb.2807386509545044/2807386456211716    https://web.archive.org/web/20201013203922if_/https://www.facebook.com/Ministry-of-Basic-and-Senior-Secondary-Education-SL-1410711375879238    https://web.archive.org/web/20201013202834/https://twitter.com/PresidentBio/status/1313156601780502530    New School Outlines:  https://web.archive.org/web/20201013205427/https://mbsse.gov.sl/wp-content/uploads/2020/09/MBSSE-Summary-Guidelines.pdf    (Oct 24) No changes since re-opening on Oct 5 with masks, temperature checks, and distancing measures.     Guidelines: https://archive.fo/SplHg  Reopening announcement on Facebook: https://archive.fo/MhRqJ

notes_E2: No policy found   https://web.archive.org/web/20200830161445/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: No evident policy change.  "Large public gatherings of over 100 people (e.g. concerts, sporting events) are prohibited."  https://web.archive.org/web/20201103175948/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/sierra-leone/coronavirus-
notes_C6: As of January 21, 2021, new inter-district travel restrictions and a curfew from 10PM until 5AM have been reinstated. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20210126030944/https://sl.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C8: Lungi International Airport opened on 22nd July. Passengers entering Sierra Leone have to have a negative covid-19 PCR test from 72 hours before entry.   "Health officials will collect temperature, basic health screening data, and seat number on  arrival. All passengers shall be subjected to a mandatory COVID-19 test upon arrival."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806141739/https://www.afro.who.int/sites/default/files/2020-07/Sierra%20Leone%20Travel%20Advisory%20July%202020.pdf    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806141727/https://www.thesierraleonetelegraph.com/sierra-leones-lungi-international-airport-reopens-wednesday-22-july-says-president-bio/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200806141538/https://statehouse.gov.sl/wp-content/uploads/2020/06/Statement-by-His-Excellency-Dr-Julius-Maada-Bio-President-of-the-Republic-of-Sierra-Leone-at-the-Fourth-Press-Conference-on-Covid-19.-Freetown-State-House-23-June-2020.pdf
notes_C2: On January 25, authorities slammed a ban on nightclub activities, and all restaurants and bars were banned from operating during weekends.  Link: https://archive.vn/FPbYI
notes_C4: Adjusted to "3" since finding documentation of the below limits, and we are to record the stricter policy:    "Sporting activities and large gatherings (any group more than 10 people) at the beach and  sports/video centers are still not allowed at this time."    "Traditional events like funerals, weddings, and naming ceremonies are times to show our love for  one another. Let’s help protect our loved ones by limiting such events to 35 people, wearing cloth  masks, and keeping a safe distance of at least one meter or arms-stretched length, from each  other."    https://web.archive.org/web/20201103140942/http://dhse.gov.sl/wp-content/uploads/2020/10/GoSL_COVID-19_Message-Guide_Volume-6_2020OCT23.pdf
notes_C5: As of a recent update on the US embassy website, the government has imposed restrictions on the number of passengers traveling by public transportation. See: https://web.archive.org/web/20201123092033/https://lr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: El Salvador
notes_H1: Social Media awareness campaign started. [https://web.archive.org/web/20200514123506/https://www.facebook.com/salud.sv/photos/a.999439960078450/2894128407276253/?type=3&theater=] https://www.facebook.com/salud.sv/photos/a.999439960078450/2894128407276253/?type=3&theater
notes_H3: no indication of contact tracing anywhere.
notes_H2: Diagnostic booths carry out COVID-19 tests on citizens.  "Some 40 COVID-19 detection tests were carried out in one of the two Diagnostic Booths that traveled to the Government Center, on the outskirts of the Legislative Assembly, this Friday, April 24. [...] The examination is free for the entire population, which could detect a greater number of positive cases. 'We are ready as long as the pandemic lasts. We hope to reach more remote places to make more samples,' added Rodríguez."    [https://web.archive.org/web/20200514140439/https://www.elsalvador.com/noticias/nacional/covid-19-prueba-pandemia-cabina-salud/708854/2020/]
notes_C7: Possible movement restrictions of indeterminate duration in and out of municipalities with high positivity rates might be in place. Outside these municipalities there are no restrictions. "The Salvadoran Ministry of Health can place municipalities under special quarantine with little or no prior notice when a high number of COVID-19 cases is detected."    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201010100434/https://sv.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: On March 11,  the president of El Salvador ordered the suspension of schools for 21 days: https://web.archive.org/web/20200514111857/https://www.mined.gob.sv/noticias/item/1015483-el-ministerio-de-educacion-informa-a-la-poblacion-en-general.html  On March 21, the Executive Branch ordered national quarantine for the following 30 days with very few exceptions. The decree may be found here: https://web.archive.org/web/20200514112011/https://www.diariooficial.gob.sv/diarios/do-2020/03-marzo/21-03-2020.pdf  On April 10, guidelines on remote teaching were issued by the Ministry of Education: https://web.archive.org/web/20200514112030/http://www.mined.gob.sv/jdownloads/Circulares%20Institucionales/Circulares%202020/CIRCULAR%209-2020.pdf
notes_H6: Anyone exiting their house must wear facial coverings    https://web.archive.org/web/20210207035443/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/el-salvador/coronavirus
notes_E2: 3-month deferral of utility payments; 3-month extension for income tax payments for taxpayers operating in the tourism sector;  taxpayers operating in the electricity and telecommunication provision sectors, and all taxpayers with a tax obligation below US$ 10,000; 3-month exemption from the special tourism tax for companies operating in the tourism industry. https://web.archive.org/web/20200516104204/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: Since April 1, the government has granted a one-time US$ 300 subsidy to certain households with necessities to purchase food. The support replaces less than 50% of the lost salary. The support is not limited to formal workers. Here’s the links:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200429213135/https://www.presidencia.gob.sv/presidente-nayib-bukele-confirma-la-entrega-del-subsidio-de-300-a-750000-familias/  http://web.archive.org/save/https://recursos.elsalvador.com/documentos/2020/04/ABANSA.pdf
notes_C3: 19th September 2020 onward, PHASE 4: El Salvador APPROACHING THE NEW NORMALITY (Saturday, September 19 to Saturday, October 3, 2020), Shows and public sporting events open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200929044116/https://www.lexology.com/library/detail.aspx?g=a3c98387-9415-4a9f-9452-c91e1223adb6
notes_C6: Considering the reopening of the economy on the 24th of August and the absence of a curfew, as well as provisions for all businesses to be open and calls to respect biosecurity prevention measures, staying at home is only recommended    https://web.archive.org/web/20210208225931/https://consortiumlegal.com/el-salvador-ley-especial-transitoria-para-contener-la-pandemia-por-la-enfermedad-covid-19/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210207035443/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/el-salvador/coronavirus
notes_C8: Travellers having visited the UK or South Africa in the past 30 days are banned from entering the country, unless they are of Salvadoran citizenship   https://web.archive.org/web/20210208224147/https://sv.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: The "new normality" is in place in El Salvador since August 24, and it involves the reopening of restaurants, malls and public transportation. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200908050613/https://www.infobae.com/america/agencias/2020/08/25/tras-estricta-cuarentena-el-salvador-se-acerca-a-normalidad/
notes_C4: Gatherings are discouraged, no formal changes found   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207035443/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/el-salvador/coronavirus
notes_H7: El Salvador has begun administering the AstraZeneca vaccines to priority group 1 (Key workers A) on February 24, 2021, according to the office of the El Salvadorian president.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308005009/https://www.salud.gob.sv/febrero-2021-el-salvador-ya-figura-en-la-lista-mundial-de-paises-que-han-iniciado-la-vacunacion-anti-covid-19/    http://web.archive.org/web/20210308005506/https://www.presidencia.gob.sv/gobierno-de-el-salvador-autoriza-la-importacion-distribucion-y-uso-de-la-vacuna-contra-el-covid-19-de-la-firma-astrazeneca/
notes_C5: Public transportation is operating and available to the public. Taxis and other private transportation companies are also operating normally. The Government of El-Salvador recommends wearing a mask at all times.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201010100434/https://sv.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: San Marino
notes_H1: Covid-19 hotline active since February 25. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200226181438/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/italia-c7/coronavirus-anziani-vittime-del-virus-e-degli-sciacalli-e-r-attiva-numero-verde-a184161 // Official information also available in  http://web.archive.org/web/20200606125109/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home.html
notes_H3: "In San Marino there is an event-based surveillance system in place and the country has the ability to quickly enhance current surveillance (this enhancement is in place for Covid-19) and the specific case and contact definitions and other criteria for investigation have been added to the system." Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200507173122/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/sanmarino/livinghit.aspx?Section=1.3%20Isolation%20and%20quarantine&Type=Chapter
notes_H2: voluntary testing is suspended to give priority to contact tracing  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_C7: internal movement is possible with some restrictions  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_C1: schools reopen after christmas break, high schools still on virtual learning  https://web.archive.org/web/20210110184644/http://www.iss.sm/on-line/home/documento49121874.html
notes_H6: "open spaces also are allowed provided they are in static form, it is expected to use requirement of protective equipment"  http://web.archive.org/web/20201101201343/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/attualita-c4/san-marino-emesso-il-decreto-n-193-in-vigore-dalle-18-di-venerdi-a196334  May not be very reliable : http://web.archive.org/web/20201101213116/https://www.tripsguard.com/destination/san-marino/
notes_E2: The key measures approved by the government include: i) suspension of payment deadlines for government tax and non-tax obligations, utility bills, and other dues to provide liquidity to the private sector; ii) temporary freeze of all non-essential government spending and reduction in public sector wage bill to redirect spending to the health sector; and iii) extension of supplemental wage scheme to support workers displaced by COVID-19 containment measures; iv) deferral of income tax payment; v)minimum guaranteed income for poorer households; vi) other measures to support businesses, including tax credits, tax payments postponement and rescheduling. Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200729163904/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: "Viene introdotto, "dal 1° marzo 2020 e fino alla data di cessazione della emergenza sanitaria", il reddito minimo garantito per le famiglie, "già costituiti alla data del 1° marzo 2020, anche se composti da una persona sola, che si trovano in stato di difficoltà economica e con insufficienti mezzi di sostentamento". L'importo erogato alle famiglie bisognose sarà di 580 euro mensili per ogni nucleo familiare, maggiorato di 150 euro per il coniuge o per il convivente more uxorio o per il contraente l’unione civile, e di 50 euro per ogni altro convivente del nucleo familiare." Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200606125817/http://www.libertas.sm/notizie/2020/04/22/san-marino-coronavirus-decreto-a-favore-di-imprese-operatori-lavoratori-e-famiglie.html
notes_C3: Theatres and cinemas remain open, and religious ceremonies, including weddings and funerals are allowed.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222091520/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
notes_C6: "Please note that a curfew is currently in force in the Republic of San Marino from 10 p.m. to 5 a.m. Internal travel within San Marino territory are allowed from 5 a.m. to 10 p.m. It is compulsory to wear the mask properly, both outdoors and indoors, except when being alone or together with cohabitants. The above obligation shall not apply to children under the age of six, people with forms of disability that are not compatible with the continuous use of the mask and people interacting with them. Plexiglass face shields and fabric masks are not allowed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314134809/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/en/home/right-banners/information-covid-19.html
notes_C8: Entryinto the Republic of San Marino, for those who come from countries other than Italy and Vatican City, or who have stayed outside these two countries in the previous 14 days, is allowed against the presentation of a special certificate certifying the negativity to the coronavirus, through molecular buffer subposition in the 48 hours before entering the territory, or of a special certificate of anti-SARS-CoV-2 vaccination.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201155314/http://www.esteri.sm/on-line/home/link/informazioni-per-chi-viaggia.html  https://web.archive.org/web/20210222091520/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
notes_C2: "All visitors must comply with social distancing and sanitisation regulations. You will also be required to wear a face mask on public transport, in all indoor public spaces, and in outdoor spaces where it is not possible to maintain 1 metre social distancing.    Bars and restaurants remain open, but must close between the hours of midnight and 4:30am. Only six people may sit together at a table and it is not allowed to consume food standing at the bar.    Theatres and cinemas remain open, and religious ceremonies, including weddings and funerals are allowed."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210314135206/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/san-marino/coronavirus
notes_C4: max 6 persons for private gatherings
notes_C5: Public transportation has been restablished on May 4. Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200517044419/https://www.sanmarinortv.sm/news/comunicati-c9/start-romagna-da-lunedi-via-alla-fase-2-del-trasporto-pubblico-locale-in-romagna-a187741

name: Somalia
notes_H1: The Somali health minister on Monday has warned that the COVID-19 situation in the Horn of African country is "dire" and called for strict adherence to health measures in fighting the disease.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308161949/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/somali-government-warns-covid-19-situation-is-dire/2160417
notes_H3: According to the US embassy website, Somali authorities have established a quarantine unit at Aden Adde International Airport (AAIA) in Mogadishu to isolate passengers who demonstrate symptoms of coronavirus.  http://web.archive.org/web/20200829182419/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H2: "Since then the WHO country office has shipped over 150 samples collected from different parts of the country to KEMRI and many of them have tested positive. Considering that the country would need to build its testing capacity rapidly for COVID-19 and decentralize laboratory testing in order to rapidly isolate and treat cases while tracking close contacts in line with WHO’s strategy to “Test, track and treat” for detecting and preventing community transmission, 3 laboratories with molecular testing facility were rapidly established by WHO in April with the financial support from the Italian Development Cooperation. These laboratories were established in Mogadishu, Garowe and Hargeisa."         https://archive.fo/U23qj
notes_C7: No information to suggest a change in policy.
notes_C1: "Somalia Monday [22/02/21] closed all schools and universities for two weeks as COVID-19 infections rise in the Horn of Africa nation."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228123108/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/latest-on-coronavirus-outbreak/covid-19-schools-shut-for-2-weeks-in-somalia/2153590
notes_H6: Somalia on Monday [1st March] made the face masks mandatory after rise in COVID-19 cases amid a deadlier second wave.  Omar Mohamud Mohamed Filish, mayor of Mogadishu, the largest and most populated city in the country, announced the use of face masks in all public places mandatory amid the rising numbers of coronavirus cases and deaths.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152335/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/somalia-deadlier-2nd-wave-makes-face-masks-mandatory/2160893
notes_E2: In response to the second wave of the virus, tax relief on core basic food commodities (rice, cooking oil, flour, dates, etc.) was reinstated from March 2021.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: "The government has banned public gatherings citing the pandemic"    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228121759/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/as-somalias-covid19-cases-surge-a-variant-is-suspected-somalia-covid-patients-people-coronavirus-b1807811.html
notes_C6: US embassy: "On April 15, 2020, the Federal Government of Somalia imposed a nighttime curfew from 8:00 p.m. to 5:00 a.m."  Anadolu News Agency: "a curfew was imposed for less than a month in April last year"  Suggests the curfew is not enforced though may not have been formally discontinued.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222101734/https://so.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222102837/https://www.aa.com.tr/en/africa/is-somalia-ignoring-coronavirus-pandemic/2138302
notes_C8: On Tuesday [2nd March] the information minister said that all passengers arriving in the country will be required to have negative results from valid polymerase chain reaction (PCR) COVID-19 tests done within 72 hours and will have to undergo a mandatory seven-day quarantine.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308153906/https://allafrica.com/stories/202103040185.html
notes_C2: On 3rd March Somalia announced the closure of government offices and sports arenas for two weeks. All staff were told to work from home unless they provide essential services.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210308153906/https://allafrica.com/stories/202103040185.html
notes_C4: "The government has banned public gatherings citing the pandemic"  Can't find information on the number of people. Take this to mean gatherings in this size range are banned.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210228121759/https://www.independent.co.uk/news/as-somalias-covid19-cases-surge-a-variant-is-suspected-somalia-covid-patients-people-coronavirus-b1807811.html

name: Serbia
notes_H1: Government launches Coronavirus website: https://covid19.rs/
notes_H3: Predrag Kon (head of the Infectious Diseases Unit of the City Institute of Public Health and government spokesperson on epidemiology): "some parts of the health care system will be severely burdened simply because it is necessary to trace all those contacts. In this case, fortunately, because of his self-isolation and his independent decision to quarantine, we do not have such a huge number [of cases]"  -> This indicates the presence of comprehensive contact tracing for the first contact.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200407232501/https://balkaninsight.com/2020/03/06/serbia-confirms-first-case-of-coronavirus/
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health published a list of health centers where people showing COVID-19 symptoms get COVID-19 PCR tests.   Link: https://archive.fo/wip/JCFv8
notes_C7: PM explained that the introduction of more stringent measures was necessary, and expressed hope that in five to ten days they will contribute to reducing the number of infected people in Belgrade, where the situation is the most critical.    According to her, a ban on movement and curfew would undoubtedly be the most effective measure, because it was already seen in March and April that it contributed to reducing the number of infected people in a short time.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200718091317/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/158523/restrictive-measures-to-help-curb-coronavirus.php
notes_C1: The Education Ministry said earlier that elementary and high schools would reopen using the same model for classes that was in place since September 1 which means that elementary school children in grades 1 to 4 will go to school every day in smaller groups while grades 5 to 8 will go to school every other day and online. High school students will either go to school one week and have online classes every other week or stay at home for online schooling to the end of the year. Classes will be 30 minutes long instead of the customary 45 and the school year will be five days longerr because of the coronavirus pandemic.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210118234843/https://rs.n1info.com/english/news/serbian-schools-start-second-semester-teachers-unhappy/
notes_H6: "The use of face coverings is required in all indoor locations, as well as outdoors when required physical distancing is not possible, for example waiting in line to enter stores or at bus stops.  Face coverings are recommended elsewhere outdoors."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200921080116/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/
notes_E2: The Minister of Finance announced the deferral of payment of payroll taxes and contributions for all private companies during the state of emergency, and for a minimum of three months, deferral of payment of income tax for the second quarter of 2020 and exemption from VAT for all those who donate and deal with donations. Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200501000306/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/152964/state-sets-aside-51b-to-mitigate-coronavirus-economic-blow.php
notes_E1: The Government of the Republic of Serbia launched the second aid package on 30 July. 'This package includes the payment of 60 percent of the minimum wage twice , as well as the postponement of taxes and contributions on wages for one month, and it is worth 66 billion dinars [c.667 million US$].' The benefits will be paid in two times, one by 10 August and another in September.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806165949/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/480712/usvojen-pravni-okvir-za-sprovodjenje-drugog-paketa-ekonomskih-mera.php
notes_C3: From 1st July, sports and entertainment events banned. https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: From 24 November, the Serbian government adopted new measures to suppress the epidemic caused by the COVID-19 infectious disease, whose implementation will begin on 24 November 2020. Including, but not limited to:  Strict control of the implementation of home isolation, house quarantine (self-isolation), as well as all other anti-epidemic measures in force.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201219200700/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163819/government-passes-new-anti-coronavirus-measures.php
notes_C8: "Deputy Director of the Institute of Public Health of Serbia "Dr Milan Jovanovic Batut" Darija Kisic Tepavcevic said that the COVID-19 crisis response team proposed to the government to make a decision that all citizens coming to Serbia from the territory of Croatia, North Macedonia, Bulgaria and Romania should have a negative PCR test that is not older than 48 hours.    In a statement to the press after the session of the COVID-19 crisis response team, she explained that the decision is valid from tomorrow,15 August, and does not refer to our citizens who come from the territory of those countries."    http://web.archive.org/web/20200817062634/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/159955/mandatory-pcr-test-for-citizens-of-four-neighbouring-countries.php
notes_C2: On July 1 in response to a new wave of infections, the government introduced new measures including limiting hours of operation for restaurants and bars; and closure of swimming pools, spa and wellness centres.   https://web.archive.org/web/20200903125436/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C4: No major changes    6-Nov - Ban on gathering of more than five persons introduced - the number of persons that can gather in an open and closed space reduced from 30 to five.    Link 1 - https://archive.fo/vfyta  Link 2 - https://web.archive.org/web/20201116224059/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/163210/ban-on-gathering-of-more-than-five-persons-introduced.php
notes_H7: Sputnik V, Pfizer-BioNTech and Sinovac are used.  All people can registered for vaccination but not coded 5 since since the country does not have currently enough vaccines  (had 1,170,000 doses). Contracts have been signed for more than 6.5 million vaccines, and on February 1 and 2 more contracts will be signed according to the Prime minister, which will bring the total number of purchased vaccines to 11 million.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210201210655/https://www.srbija.gov.rs/vest/en/167043/serbia-has-vaccinated-438000-people.php
notes_C5: Intercity, urban and suburban bus and rail services have resumed as of 17/5.http://web.archive.org/web/20200521212855/https://rs.usembassy.gov/serbia-covid-19-information/

name: South Sudan
notes_H1: President Salva Kiir Addresses the Nation on COVID-19 (sharing prevention strategies with the public) Link: https://web.archive.org/web/20200601142549/https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wm_x0scA4KI https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Wm_x0scA4KI
notes_H3: The last situation report had 153 contacts due to be traced for the period between 7th and 13th of December 2020. There is no new information for this timeframe. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207232346/https://moh.gov.ss/documents/Week%2050_COVID-19_SitRep.pdf
notes_H2: COVID-19 testing is available for those with symptoms in South Sudan, however it is limited due to a shortage of testing kits. Travelers arriving in South Sudan will receive a test if they exhibit active signs of COVID-19 infection. COVID-19 testing is available through the South Sudan Rapid Response Team by calling 6666 or by presenting to a health facility.  COVID-19 testing is available but limited for outbound international travelers who need a negative COVID-19 certificate for arrival to their destination. The John Garang Infectious Disease Unit in Juba has 250 tests for travelers available per day. Testing is available 7 days a week, 9:00 a.m.-2:00 p.m. Tests require pre-registration the day before the test is to be administered; pre-registration is done in person at 7am at the testing facility. Results are available 1-2 days after testing. Testing is free of charge.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201209215506/https://ss.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: /web/20210222171844/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirusAn official government curfew is in force across South Sudan from 10pm to 6amThere are also some restrictions on public transport and inter-state movements
notes_C1: Public places and services  Hotels are open to the public. Shops, restaurants and businesses are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Public rallies are not allowed, schools are partially closed, and public gatherings for funerals are limited to a maximum of 50 people.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210111140748/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
notes_H6: Required on public transport    /web/20210222171844/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus
notes_E1: 28 April policy change is incorrect as it reflects a World Bank policy. Therefore changing this indicator to 0.
notes_C3: There is a ban on these type of social gatherings including churches and mosques. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210207234320/https://twitter.com/SouthSudanGov/status/1357052509458731009/photo/1
notes_C6: According to the government, non-essential workers should be give provision to stay at home by employers or work on a shift basis. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210207234320/https://twitter.com/SouthSudanGov/status/1357052509458731009/photo/1
notes_C8: "All passengers, excepted as stated in the following bullet point, must possess a certified negative polymerise chain reaction (PCR) test certificate dated within 96 hours of arrival. Persons 6 years old and younger are exempt."    "Effective immediately, the Sudanese Civil Aviation Authority passengers who originate from or transit through the UK, South Africa, and the Netherlands must possess a certified negative polymerise chain reaction test certificated dated within 72 hours of arrival.  These passengers are subject to a mandatory 14-day home quarantine."    https://web.archive.org/web/20210118162213/https://sd.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: /web/20210222171844/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/south-sudan/coronavirus  Hotels, shops and restaurants are open but subject to strict social distancing, even if it is not consistently observed. Businesses which attract a crowd, including bars and nightclubs, are closed
notes_C4: According to the government, all social gatherings are banned including the churches and mosques. Please see:   https://web.archive.org/web/20210207234320/https://twitter.com/SouthSudanGov/status/1357052509458731009/photo/1
notes_C5: According to the government, public transportation is reduced to half capacity for bus and taxi. For the Raksha; two passengers and the bodaboda to cargo transport or strictly one passenger as long as there is a mask. Please see: https://web.archive.org/web/20210207234320/https://twitter.com/SouthSudanGov/status/1357052509458731009/photo/1

name: Suriname
notes_H1: On Saturday, March 14, 2020, the government held a press conference that extensively discussed the latest state of affairs regarding the outbreak of the COVID 19 virus in our country.
