Every day at 6 p.m., the community can count on the latest news.  /web/20200510055526/https://covid-19.sr/corona-in-suriname/
notes_H3: You should immediately call number 178. Then the investigation process starts.  • Test material is taken from the patient (preferably at home) and then the material is tested to AZP and CL.  • If a person does not need extra care, home quarantine takes place for 14 days (possibly with surveillance), provided the test is positive.  • If a patient has complaints, that patient is taken to AZP (Paramaribo) or MMC (Nickerie). These clinics have trained personnel (SARI) in taking samples for the lab. And the patient is transferred to the quarantine unit.  • Housemates of the suspect case must also stay home under surveillance during the incubation period.  • Treatment must be done according to protocol.   /web/20200510170255/https://covid-19.sr/covid-19/
notes_H2: From Suriname's epidemiologist speaking on 27 July:  "Doctor Ori says it is aiming to conduct mobile COVID-19 tests again this week. The RGD now also has mobile test units in eleven places. “The procedure there is somewhat different. The opportunity to step there and have yourself tested is not available now.”  http://archive.fo/10aH1    This indicates that testing is limited to symptomatic individuals, and therefore meets a coding of 2
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923123510/https://sr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information
notes_C1: Primary schools reopened from the 15th February 2021 with appropriate social distancing and hygiene measures.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210228162958/http://health.gov.sr/actueel/2021/regering-past-lockdown-maatregelen-aan/
notes_H6: It is mandatory to wear a face mask outside.  https://sr.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-paramaribo-suriname-31/
notes_E2: On 9 April 2020, Suriname’s Minister of Finance issued an announcement with tax measures to alleviate the cash flow challenges faced by corporations and individuals due to COVID-19. The tax measures include:  1:Extension of tax return filing dates  2Based on the applicable Suriname tax legislation, any amount due and payable upon the filing of the preliminary tax returns for the year 2020, could be paid in four equal instalments on 15 April, 15 July, 15 October and 31 December 2020.  3:Taxpayers who are experiencing cash flow challenges because of COVID-19 can submit a substantiated request to the Tax Collector of Direct Taxes to qualify for a deferred payment arrangement  3:The statutory filing and payment due date for the turnover tax returns is the 16th of each month. Whereas, wage tax returns should be filed and any tax due should be paid by the 7th business day following the previous month. The tax authorities will be lenient with these filing and payment dates for the taxable periods of March, April, May and June 2020, provided the taxpayer submits a request for the postponement of the filing of the returns and payment of any wage tax or turnover tax due on these returns.  Link Lin:https://web.archive.org/web/20200611111255/https://www.ey.com/en_gl/tax-alerts/suriname-announces-tax-measures-to-mitigate-impact-of-covid-19
notes_C3: he Government of Suriname has announced that it is instituting a “total” lockdown that will last from 1800 on Thursday, June 4, until 0600 hours on Friday, June 12. This means that all residents of the country should stay at home except for short trips for essential needs.  Linkhttps://web.archive.org/web/20200611101527/https://www.osac.gov/Content/Report/feb64421-b9e6-477b-9a97-18e1807ac1d7
notes_C6: The curfew in place since December 22 has been extended. Curfew is in place daily between 7 pm and 5 am.   sources: https://archive.vn/vRT2Q  https://archive.vn/XhPpe
notes_C8: All international borders remain closed.   source: https://archive.vn/CivJf  "All commercial passenger flights are banned from entry, with only cargo flights and specially permitted repatriation flights allowed. Domestic flights are also restricted to cargo transport, repatriations, and emergency flights."  source:https://archive.vn/DlaJW
notes_C2: Total lockdown ended on September 14.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923125829/https://sr.usembassy.gov/health-alert-u-s-embassy-paramaribo-suriname-37/
notes_C4: "Gathering: maximum 10 people. This also applies to funeral services"  https://web.archive.org/web/20210111204403/http://health.gov.sr/actueel/2020/overheid-verscherpt-covid-19-maatregelen/
notes_H7: Vaccination programme begins with frontline health workers receiving the first doses of the AstraZeneca vaccine from the 23rd February 2021. The vaccines were donated to Suriname by Barbados and India.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210228172005/http://health.gov.sr/actueel/2021/kick-off-covid-19-vaccinatie-een-feit/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210224023852if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/health-coronavirus-suriname-vaccine/suriname-begins-coronavirus-vaccination-campaign-with-donated-doses-idUSL1N2KT2EE  https://web.archive.org/web/20210228171846/http://health.gov.sr/actueel/2021/minister-ramadhin-kondigt-start-covid-19-vaccinatiecampagne-aan/
notes_C5: Public transportation is operating and taxis and buses are available.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200923123510/https://sr.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information

name: Slovak Republic
notes_H1: Government started to regularly inform the public about the developments concerning coronavirus, based on the Facebook account of the Cabinet of PM https://www.facebook.com/UradVladySR/ In addition to the regular updates by the Ministry of Health since 27 January 2020 https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanky?stranka=8 http://web.archive.org/web/20200520114315/https://www.health.gov.sk/Clanky?stranka=8
notes_H2: "Once travelers register with the Regional Office of Public Health upon entry, they will receive information about where to get tested after their fifth day of home quarantine. The Slovak government pays for COVID-19 testing in these cases. Once they receive negative test results, free movement in Slovakia is permitted.  Private testing is also available at www.lab.online.sk or www.medirex.sk in various locations throughout the country. If not ordered by the Regional Public Health Authority or a medical provider, the fee for testing is paid by the traveler. The standard cost is €50-€60."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200914173717/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C7: From 07 January, movement within the Nitra region, including to work and for essential errands, is only permissible with the results of a negative COVID-19 test taken within the last 7 days.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210109224013/https://korona.gov.sk/tlacove-spravy/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210109220424/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C1: From 08 February, some schools decided to physically re-open, while others decided to stay with distance education.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192819/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/v-malackach-sa-skoly-otvarat-nebudu-pokracuju-v-distancnom-vzdelavani/  https://web.archive.org/web/20210213192940/https://bratislavskykraj.sk/prezencne-vyucovanie-sa-obnovilo-na-styroch-zupnych-skolach/
notes_H6: The code was changed to 4T since the requirements on wearing a mask differ between the Warning II (pink) zone and Warning III (red)/Warning IV (black) zones. Slovak regions are in Warning II to Warning IV zones.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210301135619/https://sk.usembassy.gov/wp-content/uploads/sites/193/Feb-5-Traffic-Light-System.pdf
notes_E2: The government announced the possibility to defer mortgage and loan repayments by 1 to 9 months for sole proprietors, small and medium-sized companies  medium-sized companies. In addition it also announced an automatic postponement of the deadline for filing a tax return until the end of the month following the end of the pandemic period.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200518210520/https://korona.gov.sk/pomoc-zamestnancom/
notes_E1: According to the Budapest Business Journal, the Prime Minister announced 1.5 billion Euros per month to refund 80% of salaries received by people employed in facilities that have been obliged to close. Compensation will also be offered to the self-employed and employees depending on the drop in revenues of the affected businesses.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200518201927/https://bbj.hu/region/slovak-govt-drafts-first-aid-economic-package-due-to-coronavirus_180667
notes_C3: "A ban is imposed on organising mass sporting, cultural, entertainment, social events, or events of other nature with more than 50 attendees at one time. If the number of persons at the above events performing on the organiser’s behalf exceeds 50 persons (performers, athletes, sports event organisers, etc.), a mass event will be held without live audience.    In parallel, it is prohibited to:    organise mass, cultural, entertainment, social gatherings or gatherings of other nature (discotheques, dance events, etc.) in catering establishments (restaurants, bars, nightclubs, bars, etc.) and in accommodation facilities. The restriction does not apply to the regular provision of catering services in food establishments,  organise large social gatherings (wedding  receptions, celebrations, dance balls, funeral feasts, green ribbon parties of students, etc.)."    http://web.archive.org/web/20201013192040/https://korona.gov.sk/en/platne-hygienicke-opatrenia-okt-en/
notes_C6: "Slovakia will shut most of its schools and require the population to stay home apart from work, essential shopping and nature trips, in a partial lockdown to slow the spread of the coronavirus"  https://web.archive.org/web/20201029225257if_/https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSKBN2772PF
notes_C8: "Should you enter the territory of the Slovak Republic as of 1 September, 7:00 a.m., and:    You have visited an EU country not mentioned on the list of less-risky countries:  You are obliged to self-isolate,  If you have symptoms you are obliged to get tested for COVID-19 on the fifth day of your self-isolation at the latest,  If you are asymptomatic, your self-isolation is completed after your 10- day self-isolation period is over,  Self-isolation is also mandatory for persons living with you in a common household.  You have visited a country which is not an EU member and is not mentioned on the list of less-risky countries:  You are obliged to self-isolate  You are obliged to get tested for COVID-19 on the fifth day of self-isolation at the latest  Self-isolation is also mandatory for persons living with you in a common household."    https://web.archive.org/web/20200914174304/https://korona.gov.sk/en/travelling-to-slovakia-and-covid19/
notes_C2: "Following the nationwide testing and curfew, the pandemic commission decided on lifting some measures that were imposed to fight the coronavirus.      As a result, cinemas, theatres and churches were open on November 16, while some sports competitions were given a green light, although without spectators. On the other hand, restaurants, hotels and also schools remain closed for now."    Source: The Slovak Spectator, an independent English-language newspaper     http://web.archive.org/web/20201130220822/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22536069/coronavirus-in-slovakia-measures-in-place-after-november-16.html
notes_C4: 1 January 2021     From January the 1st, under the partial lockdown restrictions, family units are not allowed to mix with others from outside of the household.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210118155140/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/     Due to the rising number of COVID-19 cases people were no longer allowed to form bubbles after 1 January 2021. While the decree that sets out the rules for movement and gatherings since 1 January does not explicitly ban gatherings. The rules governing the movement of people are strict and make it nearly impossible for people to gather without breaking any of the movement restrictions.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210125115028/https://www.slov-lex.sk/pravne-predpisy/SK/ZZ/2020/453/20201231      At the same time, the limit for people attending christenings, funerals and weddings remains at 6, see:     https://web.archive.org/web/20210114175952/http://www.minv.sk/swift_data/source/verejna_sprava/vestnik_vlady_sr_rok_2021/ciastka_2_2021.pdf
notes_H7: Update immunization policy is in place from 18 January – currently health care professionals and other workers in health care facilities are eligible + newly also old people in nursing homes. People from critical infrastructure will be moved to the list of replacements, meaning they will receive the vaccination only if there is unused vaccine or someone fails to attend.    In the second phase:  residents of senior's homes and people over 65, patients with serious diagnoses, such as diabetes, oncological diseases, auto-immune diseases, cardiovascular issues and other chronic diseases     In the third phase: people in communities with a high risk of fast coronavirus spread like teachers, people living in marginalised Roma communities, homeless people and asylum seekers    In the fourth phase: members of the general public older than 18     https://web.archive.org/web/20210118213749/https://spectator.sme.sk/c/22574807/vaccination-strategy-to-change.html
notes_C5: Local public transport is running normally in Slovakia, but face masks are required.    There is not an exact policy change occurring on this day, however, I didn't find the exact date in which public transport went back to normal operations in the country.    http://web.archive.org/web/20200806183129/https://sk.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/

name: Slovenia
notes_H1: COVID-19 Website  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/    Coronavirus: Preparedness and measures in Slovenia and COVID-19 Helpline  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/koronavirus-preparedness-and-measures-in-slovenia/    Coronavirus: Preventing infections  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/coronavirus-preventing-infections/    Coronavirus: Symptoms of infection and treatment  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/coronavirus-symptoms-of-infection-and-treatment/    Government measures  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/government-measures/    Recommendations for washing hands cough etiquette  Link: https://www.gov.si/assets/vlada/Koronavirus-zbirno-infografike-vlada/Infografike/Anglescina/Recommendations-for-washing-hands-Cough-etiquette.pdf    Quotation: So far Slovenia has prepared hospital isolation rooms and urged citizens to be particularly careful with hygiene. Many hospitals have prohibited or limited visitations in recent days. (4th March 2020)  Link: https://www.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-slovenia-idUSKBN20R33X    COVID-19 Press Conference: Official updates on the occurrence of the coronavirus infection (7 March 2020)  Link: gov.si/en/news/2020-03-07-official-updates-on-the-occurrence-of-the-coronavirus-infection/    Latest information about coronavirus (Covid-19) in Slovenia (9 March 2020)  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-09-latest-information-about-coronavirus-covid-19-in-slovenia/    Quotation: The National Institute of Public Health (NIJZ) has drafted a leaflet with key information about the coronavirus, which will be distributed to all Slovenian households via the Post of Slovenia (10 March 2020)  Link: https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-10-measures-to-contain-the-spread-of-coronavirus-are-in-force/
notes_H3: Contact tracing becomes limited from 9 October- see  https://web.archive.org/web/20210205103845/https://www.nijz.si/sl/spremenjen-protokol-sledenja-stikom-okuzenih-z-novim-koronavirusom-sars-cov-2    Also confirmed following email conversation with researchers from covid-19.sledilnik.org
notes_H2: Testing is available for both foreign nationals and Slovenians.  No appointment is required for the rapid antigen tests (RAT), and they are available throughout the country, including Ljubljana airport.  For the PCR test, available at the Ljubljana Clinical Center, an appointment is required, but is usually available within a day.  For foreign nationals, cost for RAT is 25-30 euro; cost for PCR is 93 euro.  Results for both tests will be provided to you electronically within 24 hours.     Link: https://archive.vn/QeWgS
notes_C7: The Government adopted a new ordinance under which the restriction on movement in the Coastal-Karst region will be reinstated as of Saturday, 27 February 2021. Since the epidemiological situation is fairly comparable among the municipalities in the Coastal-Karst region, and since there is only one region that has re-entered the red phase, the Government decided that movement would be restricted throughout the entire region, and not just in the individual municipalities within that region.    Therefore, public assembly is prohibited in the Coastal-Karst region, and entry into and departure from the Coastal-Karst region is also prohibited. Schools in the region remain open.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210309052636/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2021-02-26-restrictions-on-assembly-and-movement-reinstated-in-the-coastal-karst-region-schools-remain-open/
notes_C1: Lessons can now take place on school premises for elementary school pupils, vocational secondary school students and final year secondary school students. For other students, distance learning is being carried out.    https://archive.vn/ujoen
notes_H6: Masks or other forms of protection covering the mouth and nose, and disinfection are mandatory:  in all closed public spaces,  on public transport,  in open public spaces where it is not possible to stay two metres from other people.    https://web.archive.org/web/20201022191348/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/
notes_E2: As part of an economic stimulus package of € 1 billion (2.2 percent of GDP) announced on March 9, the authorities have adopted some tax and spending measures, including (i) tax deferrals for up to 24 months or tax payments in installments in 24 months; (ii) wage subsidies for suspended workers due to pandemic-related closures and quarantined people as at July 22 and before.   Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20200730012123/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_E1: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019095117/https://www.covid19healthsystem.org/countries/slovenia/livinghit.aspx?Section=6.+Measures+in+other+sectors&Type=Chapter
notes_C3: On 19 March, the Slovenian government issued an ordinance prohibiting the movement and gathering of people in public places and areas in the Republic of Slovenia and access to public places and areas the Republic of Slovenia until further notice. There are exceptions for those going to work, grocery shopping, or being outside with members of the same household but a safe distances (1.5 meters) from other people.  Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200427180655/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-03-19-ordinance-on-the-temporary-prohibition-of-public-gathering-at-public-meetings-and-public-events-and-other-events-in-public-places-in-the-republic-of-slovenia/
notes_C6: Updating indicator.    A curfew is in place across the nation: Movement of people on the entire territory of the Republic of Slovenia is temporarily prohibited between 22:00 and 6:00.    https://archive.vn/ujoen
notes_C8: https://web.archive.org/web/20201019094355/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/380571/slovenia-authorities-to-tighten-covid-19-restrictions-nationwide-from-september-19-update-12
notes_C2: Hence, a maximum of 50 people may gather and socialise in public at the same time and same place. In addition, accommodation providers with more than 30 rooms are open and available again, as are spa accommodations, wellness centres, gyms, swimming pools, and water activities.    Until further notice, discos and night clubs remain closed, as do stores on Sundays and holidays, except for petrol stations and pharmacies, which may be open, as at July28 and even before then.  Source:  http://web.archive.org/web/20200730001344/https://www.gov.si/en/topics/coronavirus-disease-covid-19/
notes_C4: Regardless of the type of region, events, such as weddings, anniversaries, religious ceremonies and other events or gatherings are no longer allowed anywhere in Slovenia. The ordinance adopted today also restricts the gathering of people, which means that as of today not more than 6 persons are allowed to meet; the only exception applies to members of the same household if such has more than 6 family members.      https://web.archive.org/web/20201022190747/https://www.gov.si/en/news/2020-10-19-restriction-of-movement-between-statistical-regions-and-movement-at-night-and-gatherings-limited-to-no-more-than-6-people/
notes_H7: Pfizer/BionTech & Moderna & AstraZeneca vaccines     The vaccination of people older than 80 continues throughout the country today, including in Ljubljana and Ajdovšcina.    Vaccination is free for all citizens, regardless of whether they are insured or not. Funds for the purchase of vaccines and costs for vaccination are provided in the budget of the Republic of Slovenia.    5 Feb -  Slovenia started vaccinating the elderly in care homes first, as care homes recorded frequent outbreaks and suffered the most fatalities. Apart from the elderly, nursing home and hospital staff are also being vaccinated in Slovenia at the moment.    The country has also recently received the first batch of a vaccine developed by AstraZeneca, which is, however, recommended for a younger population.       Link: https://archive.vn/cwvre  https://archive.vn/OFLYU  https://archive.vn/hH21B
notes_C5: Updating indicator.    Public passenger transport can be carried out in accordance with the normal timetables. Masks are mandatory on public transport.    https://archive.vn/ujoen

name: Sweden
notes_H1: FAQ about COVID-19 (Link): https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/  Protect yourself and others from the spread of infection in different languages (Link): https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/information-pa-olika-sprak/
notes_H3: Report from 23 March suggest that Public Health Agency thinks that contact tracing would no longer be as effective and have shifted resources to focus on risk groups. The official government website as on 05 April stated that contact tracing is the responsibility of the doctors treating covid-19, and news sources indicated that some form of tracing was ongoing. Sources: 1. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132606/https://www.thelocal.se/20200320/fact-check-has-sweden-stopped-testing-people-for-the-coronavirus 2. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132712/https://www.thelocal.se/20200313/what-you-need-to-know-about-the-coronavirus-outbreak-in-sweden-your-questions-answered 3. https://web.archive.org/web/20200406132847/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/the-public-health-agency-of-sweden/communicable-disease-control/covid-19/  Other news reports seems to suggest that contact tracing has since been stopped as it is no longer considered effective or practical. However, this could not be verified officially.  Source:https://web.archive.org/web/20200423094726/https://www.thelocal.se/20200421/the-swedish-words-weve-learned-during-the-coronavirus-outbreak
notes_H2: The Government announced that it would provide free testing for anyone showing coronavirus symptoms, and conduct contact tracing for those who are infected.   https://archive.vn/wip/LpKn5
notes_C7: In force from 14 December, the Public Health Agency replaced its regional advice with national regulations and general advice, in light of the upcoming Christmas holidays. This means that previous regional advice that explicit recommended against internal travel is no longer in force. I have not changed the code (only from T to G), because the new nation-wide advice, though less explicit compared to the regional advice, still seeks to limit travel incl travel between regions, e.g. "think through whether planned trips are really necessary to carry out".     https://web.archive.org/web/20201214164556/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/skydda-dig-och-andra/jul-och-andra-hogtider/
notes_C1: For the period of 7 December until 6 January, the Public Health Agency has issued a 'recommendation' to close all high schools (gymnasieskolor - ages 16-19) for a month and move all classes online. This dose not include exams which cannot be taken at a distance. The temporary regulations give principals a certain flexibility to make decisions about their activities based on the current infection control situation or local needs. There are opportunities for the principal to take action if the school is open or if the school is or has been closed.  In line with the Interpretation Guide on C1, I have coded this as '2', since "if the situation is that all schools are closed ... then that would count as a full closure". Since principals have the authority to decide whether to close high-schools, depending on the regional situation, and this is only a recommendation - making it unlikely for upper-secondary schools to close countrywide - a Targeted flag has been selected.  http://web.archive.org/web/20201207153005/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/contentassets/27a3b8becacc47edbfa51273b4931886/beslut-2020-12-03-rekommendation-om-delvis-stangning-och-overgang-till-fjarr-eller-distansundervisning-gymnasieskolan.pdf http://web.archive.org/web/20201207154159/https://www.skolverket.se/regler-och-ansvar/coronaviruset-och-covid-19---regler-for-skolor-och-forskolor/regler-for-forskolor-och-skolor-som-ar-oppna-stangda-eller-varit-stangda-under-coronapandemin
notes_H6: In the region of Västra Götaland, from 17 February, disposable masks have to be worn on public transport at all times, not just during rush hours, as well as in situations where close contact, e.g. for extended periods of time in an indoor environment, is unavoidable.  Although this is still a mere recommendation, it is a much stronger one than the mask recommendation elsewhere in the country (limited to rush hours on public transport), so I have coded it as 2T to reflect the policy change as a result of which in practice, in this region, people will be wearing masks much more often than before.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210217212115/https://www.vgregion.se/aktuellt/nyhetslista/nya-regionala-rekommendationer-i-vastra-gotaland/  ***Updated to add note that policy language seems stronger than a recommendation
notes_E2: With regard to the debt/contract relief for households, this was previously coded as '1' on the basis of the temporary additional payment for families with housing allowance from July-December 2020. This programme was NOT extended, and the Försäkringskassan website now states:     "The temporary additional payment for families with housing allowance has ceased. The last payments to families were made in December 2020."    There are numerous other policies, but these are for companies (some also employee-oriented), but not households.     http://web.archive.org/web/20210204145802/https://www.forsakringskassan.se/english/the-coronavirus-covid-19---applicable-regulations
notes_E1: Quotation: "To reduce the risk of the virus spreading in society, the qualifying day for sick pay will be discontinued between 11 March and 31 May, in that central government will pay sickness benefit for the first day of sickness.    Central government will temporarily assume responsibility for sick pay for two months."  Link: https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/03/crisis-package-for-swedish-businesses-and-jobs/
notes_C3: "The Government is making use of the possibility in the Public Order Act (Chapter 2, Section 15) to prohibit public gatherings and events if this is necessary to combat an epidemic. The prohibition is issued in an ordinance.    The ordinance means that, as of Thursday 12 March and until further notice, it is forbidden in the whole of Sweden to hold public gatherings and events with more than 500 participants.    The Government will continuously examine the need for this ordinance and it will be revoked when the prohibition is no longer needed.    Public gatherings include demonstrations, lectures, gatherings for religious practice, theatre performances, cinema screenings and concerts.    Public events include sporting events, dance performances, markets and fairs.    For a gathering to be considered public, it is necessary for it to have been arranged for the public or for the public to have access to it, or that the gathering should be regarded as equivalent to such a gathering given the conditions that apply for access to it.    For an event to be considered public, it is necessary for it to have been arranged for the public or for the public to have access to it."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200322142423/https://www.government.se/articles/2020/03/ordinance-on-a-prohibition-against-holding-public-gatherings-and-events/
notes_C6: FT. As of 25 Mar.  "Swedish authorities have banned public gatherings of more than 500 people, closed universities and higher education colleges, and advised workers to stay at home if possible."     Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20200523152613/https://www.ft.com/content/31de03b8-6dbc-11ea-89df-41bea055720b
notes_C8: "In response to the European Council’s and the European Commission’s call for travel restrictions, the Government decided on 17 March to temporarily stop non-essential travel to Sweden from all countries except those in the EEA and Switzerland so as to mitigate the effects of the outbreak of the COVID-19 virus and reduce the spread of the disease.  The decision takes effect on 19 March and will initially apply for 30 days. This is an exceptional measure that will not apply for longer than necessary."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201112160008/https://www.government.se/press-releases/2020/03/temporary-ban-on-travel-to-sweden-due-to-covid-19/
notes_C2: On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings of over 8 people came into effect. This does not apply to most workplaces, but does affect some sectors to the point where they are required to close, such as amusement parks, markets and fairs. For theaters and cinemas, the official rule is that seated audiences of up to 300 are allowed as long as social distancing measures are adhered to, although the reality on the ground is much stricter as the regions have issued non-binding recommendations which extend the 8-people limit to seated audiences.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud    https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190831/https://www.thelocal.se/20201123/no-public-events-for-more-than-8-people-in-sweden-including-seated-events
notes_C4: On 24 Nov, a new ban on public gatherings over 8 people came into effect. For private gatherings, people are "strongly recommended" to follow the regulations for public gatherings.     https://web.archive.org/web/20201130190632/https://www.krisinformation.se/en/hazards-and-risks/disasters-and-incidents/2020/official-information-on-the-new-coronavirus/restriktioner-och-forbud
notes_H7: A, C:    The first vaccinations took place on 27 December. The Public Health Agency has recommended different phases for the vaccination, according to the need for protection of respective groups. During Phase 1, which started on 27 December, elderly living in care homes or receive home care under the Social Services Act, staff working directly with these people, and adults living with someone belonging to this risk group are eligible. Phase 2 is expected to start in February 2021.         https://web.archive.org/web/20210104161641/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/nyheter-och-press/nyhetsarkiv/2020/december/vaccinationerna-i-sverige-har-inletts/    https://web.archive.org/web/20210104162056/https://www.folkhalsomyndigheten.se/smittskydd-beredskap/utbrott/aktuella-utbrott/covid-19/vaccination-mot-covid-19/rekommendationer-for-vaccination-mot-covid-19/
notes_C5: "On April 1, Swedish Public Health Agency expanded guidance for individuals and organizations to comply with Sweden’s Law on the Prevention of the Spread of Infectious Diseases:  - Public transport companies should limit the number of passengers and adapt their schedules to avoid crowds."  Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201112192626/https://se.usembassy.gov/covid-19-coronavirus-information/

name: Eswatini
notes_H1: Swazi government has a dedicated spokesperson, advisories, public info/guidance on COVID-19. Since the government does actually start messaging on Coronavirus after this day (e.g. https://web.archive.org/web/20200302152522/https:/twitter.com/EswatiniGovern1/status/1234481721447452672), 2 is maintained as coding; https://web.archive.org/web/20200229191745/https:/twitter.com/EswatiniGovern1/status/1233771535556579330
notes_H3: After April 23, statements from the ministry of health omit "contact tracing was initiated" from any updates (still present on the April 22) and together with the rising case numbers, it is likely an indication that comprehensive contact tracing may no longer be in place, though some form of contact tracing seems to be still in place. Since the comprehensive rating was based on that specific evidence, H3 is downgraded to 1 from here on out;    https://web.archive.org/web/20200611234220/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Press-Statement-Health-23-April-2020.pdf
notes_H2: The Ministry of Health wishes to emphasize that the definition of a suspect case has  changed due to the fact that Eswatini has an established local transmission. This means all flu-like illnesses must be considered suspect cases of Coronavirus infection hence the public is encouraged to seek health care as soon as they can. https://web.archive.org/web/20200611234729/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Health-statement-5-May-COVID19.pdf
notes_C7: Temperature checks between different zones and cities. No change from previous policy, but coded in line with coding interpretation guide. See also US embassy information (https://web.archive.org/web/20210308172207/https://sz.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/).
notes_C1: All schools closed. "Government continues to monitor the situation on the ground and will only open schools when it is safer to do so."    See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).
notes_H6: Correct face mask wearing necessary in all public spaces. Lockdown extended for two weeks, following the same lockdown measures as in January.     See Prime Minister's announcement of lockdown extension (https://web.archive.org/web/20210304171429/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/APM-statement-4-March-2021.pdf) and previous guidelines (https://archive.vn/UIoo4).
notes_E2: Payment arrangements for taxpayers facing cash flow problems, waiver of penalties and interest for old tax debts. The price of fuel reduced twice and planned increases in water/electricity prices postponed.    See IMF's tracker for policy responses (https://archive.vn/hgyyZ).
notes_E1: Government is also continuing with compensatory relief to workers who suffered loss of earnings as a result of being laid off due to the devastating effects of COVID-19.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210228231850/https://translate.googleapis.com/translate_static/css/translateelement.css
notes_C3: Festive season sports tournaments are prohibited  https://web.archive.org/web/20201222133514/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/december-legal.pdf
notes_C6: Curfew in place from 11PM to 4AM, no change from the previous coder's notes and in line with my subsequent notes. I have recorded this a 2 in line with the Coding Interpretation Guide.
notes_C8: Specific conditions must be met in order to enter Eswatini:    A COVID-19 test must be performed no more than 72 hours before departure and you must be able to demonstrate a negative test result on entry  Upon arriving in Eswatini, you will be screened for COVID-19 symptoms and asked about your country of origin and any transit stops  If you do not present a negative COVID-19 result on entry, or if you display COVID-19 symptoms, you will be required to take a COVID-19 test on arrival at your own cost  You may be required to undergo a quarantine period not exceeding 14 days, or isolation as advised by the port health officers  https://web.archive.org/web/20210104091520/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/eswatini/entry-requirements
notes_C2: As of August 28th, the July 3rd PM statement is still the most recent on the SZ gov website. Per that statement, as of July 13 Casinos, cinemas, gyms, health and beauty spas and auctioneers have been allowed to open subject to hygienic measures.     In further research, I could not find any evidence that other businesses are still closed.     http://web.archive.org/web/20200716175048/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/PM-statement-3-July-2020-final.pdf
notes_C4: All gatherings of all sizes prohibited except for burials.    See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).
notes_C5: Private and local transport at 80% capacity. Public transport at 50% capacity. No local freight transport between 11PM and 4AM, unless holding a permit related to COVID-19 supplies and PPE.     See the Acting Prime Minister's Statement on COVID-19 Response Interventions, 7 January 2021, (https://web.archive.org/web/20210107115246/http://www.gov.sz/images/CORONA/Acting-PM-statement-7-January-2021-final-Restrictions.pdf).

name: Seychelles
notes_H1: https://web.archive.org/save/https://data.humdata.org/dataset/acaps-covid19-government-measures-dataset, General recommendations for social distancing and hygienic practices.
notes_H3: Contact tracing and testing by the Seychellois authorities will begin on Monday 15 March. Members of the public are reassured that public health officials have begun contact tracing, the process of identification of all persons who may have come into contact with an infected person and, to continue to follow the guidelines advocated by the Department of Health.     https://web.archive.org/save/http://www.health.gov.sc/index.php/2020/03/16/seychelles-records-first-cases-of-covid-19/    https://web.archive.org/web/20200408225720/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200408225720/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_C7: Locals are encouraged to work from home where possible; otherwise, they should only limit their travel to workplace and home locations.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201215332/https://www.garda.com/crisis24/news-alerts/434776/seychelles-authorities-maintaining-updated-covid-19-measures-as-of-jan-26-update-13
notes_C1: On 23 January, the government announced that all schools remain closed until further notice.   Link: https://archive.vn/cVoJE
notes_H6: Face masks are required on public transport, in indoor places, and any other circumstances where 1m social distancing can't be practised (including places of work and outdoor spaces).    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222124407/http://www.health.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/Public-Health-Infectious-Disease-Mandatory-Wearing-of-Face-Masks-Reg....pdf
notes_E2: The CBS also announced that commercial banks, the Development Bank of Seychelles (DBS) and the Seychelles Credit Union have agreed to consider a moratorium of six months on the repayment of principal and interest on loans to assist businesses in impacted sectors.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200608135237/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  https://www.cbs.sc/Downloads/covid19/PolicyMeasures/Press%20Conference%20Presentation%20-%20Private%20Sector%20Relief%20Scheme.pdf (Not archivable)
notes_E1: The Financial Assistance for Job Retention (FA4JR) program was announced on 20/3/20 and launched in April onwards, to pay the salaries of employees of businesses and NGOs that were negatively affected by COVID-19, to ensure that no staff were to be made redundant. See government website, archived: https://web.archive.org/web/20200918152706/http://www.finance.gov.sc/uploads/resources/FA4JR_FAQs_final.pdf AND https://web.archive.org/web/20200918152746/http://www.finance.gov.sc/press-releases/256/UPDATED-LATEST-FIGURES-FROM-THE-FINANCIAL-ASSISTANCE-FOR-JOB-RETENTION-COMMITTEE-THURSDAY-17TH-SEPTEMBER-2020
notes_C3: House parties or gatherings which include any people from outside the household are not permitted.    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222114557/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_C6: New guideline on 1st Mar: http://web.archive.org/web/20210314142029/http://www.health.gov.sc/index.php/2021/03/02/health-authorities-review-national-measures/  Additional resource from media: http://web.archive.org/web/20210314142225/http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/14433/Restaurants+can+re-open%2C+curfew+pushed+back+as+Seychelles+eases+COVID-+rules
notes_C8: New guideline for visitors  http://web.archive.org/web/20210314144837/http://tourism.gov.sc/wp-content/uploads/2020/05/Seychelles-Visitor-Travel-Advisory-4-March-2021.pdf    With immediate effect all visitors from any part of the world who have been vaccinated and are able to show  proof that they have taken the complete dose of the vaccine (the two doses) and that two weeks have elapsed  after the second dose will be allowed to enter Seychelles. However, they must provide a valid certificate of  vaccination authenticated by the local public health authorities from their country of origin and must also have  a negative PCR test taken 72 hours prior to travel. They will also be allowed free movement throughout their  stay in Seychelles.
notes_C2: Public restaurants and bars outside of hotels or guesthouses will be closed.  Public swimming pools and gyms will be closed.  All retail stores will be closed except those providing essential services, including grocery stores (which will close at 6pm on weekdays and 3pm at weekends) and hardware stores (open from 8am–12 noon).    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20210222114557/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/seychelles/coronavirus
notes_C4: From 23 January, visits outside the immediate household are banned, social gatherings are not permitted.  Link: https://archive.vn/cVoJE
notes_H7: A, B, C: Sinopharm and AZ    Administration of the first dose of the Covishield vaccine has been extended to people over 50 and over 40 years as different target groups who can receive the vaccine are covered.    http://web.archive.org/web/20210228130312/http://www.seychellesnewsagency.com/articles/14399/Seychelles+to+increase+interval+between+Covishield+doses+following+new+recommendation
notes_C5: Buses are instructed to reduce maximum capacity. Masks are required on public transportation. See: https://mu.usembassy.gov/covid-19-seychelles/ [web archive unavailable, accessed 11 January 2021, webpage last updated 7 January 2021]

name: Syria
notes_H1: There is no evidence that the "For Syria stay at home" campaign is still ongoing and no campaign seems to have been announced recently. Since the curfew and movement restrictions have ended it is likely the campaign has ended.    The website, which shows the distribution of registered Coronavirus cases in Syria, is still active.    Sources: https://archive.vn/Met25  https://archive.vn/9jv5Y
notes_H3: no noted updates via regularly used sources - https://web.archive.org/web/20210105000231/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-humanitarian-update-no-22-23-december-2020
notes_H2: https://web.archive.org/web/20200518202732/https://reliefweb.int/report/syrian-arab-republic/syrian-arab-republic-covid-19-response-update-no02-6-may-2020  OCHA  “On 16 April, the WHO Regional Office for the Eastern Mediterranean (EMRO) shared information indicating that a 53-year-old man from Al-Hasakeh City who had been admitted to Qamishli National Hospital on 27 March had died on 2 April. A test for the virus subsequently tested positive.”
notes_C7: "Beginning today, the government will lift an overnight curfew and allow movement between its provinces."  https://web.archive.org/web/20200527094103/https://www.al-monitor.com/pulse/originals/2020/05/syria-coronavirus-curfew-uptick-cases-damascus-idlib.html    "Restrictions remain in place at most other crossing points inside Syria. Abu Zendin, Um Jloud and Awn Dadat in Aleppo remain closed, as do Akeirshi and Abu Assi crossing points in Ar-Raqqa. Ghazawiyet Afrin and Al-Taiha in Aleppo are reported open for commercial traffic; the latter is also reported to be currently open for university students to move into GoS areas, in addition to some medical cases (...)"    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20201110223052/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update%20No%2011_30May2020_FINAL.pdf
notes_C1: No change.  Schools, universities and institutions are open.  In Northeast Syria schools and universities are open during restricted hours and with mandated preventative measures.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215145649/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2023_1Feb2021.pdf
notes_H6: There is no law requiring face mask usage in Syria.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215154148/https://masks4all.co/what-countries-require-masks-in-public/
notes_C3: "The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced throughout May (...) markets, restaurants, cafes, gyms, parks, theaters, cinemas and most  leisure facilities remain open, with mandated precautionary measures. Mosques and churches are open, with physical distancing requirements."    Source: https://web.archive.org/web/20201108205948if_/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2020_29Oct2020_FINAL.pdf
notes_C6: No policy in place.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215145649/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2023_1Feb2021.pdf
notes_C8: "The necessary precautions to ensure Syrians are protected from the arrival of the coronavirus were on the discussion table for government ministers at the cabinet session headed by Imad Khamis on Sunday.    The cabinet stressed the need to monitor the precautionary and preventive measures taken at all ports, land, sea and air crossings, to ensure that no cases of coronavirus occur on Syrian territory. It decided to suspend visits and trips to and from the neighboring countries of Iraq and Jordan by individuals and groups, including for purposes of religious tourism, for one month. It also suspended visits to countries that have declared a state of epidemic for two months, while conducting preventive quarantine for a period of 14 days for those coming from these countries to ensure their safety."    Sources:   https://syrianobserver.com/EN/news/56590/the-government-takes-precautionary-measures-and-forbids-visits-to-iraq-and-jordan-for-a-month.html (unable to archive)
notes_C2: The GoS continues to maintain a widespread easing of preventive measures introduced in late May, albeit with some adhoc changes, including suspension of some schools/classrooms where COVID-19 cases had been reported, and in some  locations, closures of wedding and condolence halls, restrictions on audiences for sporting events, and on celebratory  gatherings. Otherwise, markets, restaurants, gyms, theaters, cinemas and most leisure facilities are open, with mandated  precautionary measures, as are mosques and churches. Public and private transportation services have resumed, as have  schools, universities and institutions. While broad-based restrictions are not anticipated to be re-imposed due to socioeconomic impacts, it remains possible the GoS may enforce localized lockdowns.  In NES, widespread preventive measures in response to increased reported COVID-19 cases implemented in November  have been partially eased since 6 December. Shops, groceries, schools, universities and educational facilities are open  during restricted hours and with mandated preventative measures. Churches and mosques are closed, except on Fridays  and Sundays, and all mass social gatherings are prohibited. It is expected the current measures will remain in place  throughout winter and may possibly be revised should a resurgence in cases occur.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210201222016/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2023_1Feb2021.pdf
notes_C4: In Northeast Syria all mass social gatherings are restricted.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215145649/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2023_1Feb2021.pdf
notes_C5: Public transport is operational.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210215145649/https://reliefweb.int/sites/reliefweb.int/files/resources/Syria_COVID-19_Humanitarian%20Update_No%2023_1Feb2021.pdf

name: Chad
notes_H1: The government of Chad first announced that travellers who have been to China, Italy or South Korea will be quarantined for 14 days at a local health facility on 7 March 2020.     The Chad Government issued the first Health Alert on 20 March 2020. Thereafter, On 13 April 2020 the Government finalised the National Contingency Plan for Preparedness and Response to the Epidemic of Coronavirus COVID-19 to prevent the spread of the disease, the Chad Government has taken a series of measures with the major ones focused on: suspension of all international flights, closure of schools, universities, places of worship, and of non-essential businesses, a ban on public transport, closure of the main markets and a curfew in the capital of N’Djamena and 4 provinces of Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-kebbi Ouest and Mayo-kebbi Est.     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080941/https://reliefweb.int/report/chad/chad-coronavirus-covid-19-situation-report-no-1   https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080113/https://www.cnbcafrica.com/africa-press-office/2020/03/20/health-alert-u-s-embassy-ndjamena-chad/     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501071153/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19#C     https://web.archive.org/web/20200501080336/https://www.iata.org/contentassets/b308ae421f9d4f83bec899ea64a04ffc/chad-ncov-measures.pdf
notes_H3: The Chadian government reported to the WHO that “As of February 26, 847 contacts associated with the confirmed cases, of which 846 have been followed.” A 19 February OCHA quick alert notes that “In the provinces, most cases are contact cases whereas in N’Djamena they are travelers” alluding to contact tracing. An existing library of daily situation reports prepared by the Chadian government for the WHO and OCHA report consistent contact tracing since March 2020.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301020941/https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/sites/www.humanitarianresponse.info/files/documents/files/sitrep_covid-19_n340_26_fevrier_-_2021.pdf    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301023332/https://reliefweb.int/report/chad/chad-quick-alerts-19-february-2021     Library of Daily OCHA/WHO Situation Reports:  https://web.archive.org/web/20210301022341/https://www.humanitarianresponse.info/en/operations/chad/documents/themes/covid-19
notes_H2: No new change found
notes_C7: The US embassy reports that there are currently no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. Since January 20, 2021 restrictions have been gradually relaxed throughout the country.    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210228191046/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210301023652/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C1: I am unable to find any information that supports school closure.  US Embassy - Shows all University and schools are fully open.  I see the information on UK Government site calls out quarantine measures in the capital but it calls out restricting entry and exit, restricting movement & public gatherings, but nothing of schools being closed.  But I also found this IMF site that shows as of January 20th restrictions that have been gradually lifted for everything.  I am coding to the no measures as 2 out of 3 sources support the opening.    https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194118/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194213/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_H6: Wearing of face masks when outdoors is compulsory throughout the country with penalties, including potential imprisonment, for non-compliance. Source:
notes_E2: FISCAL  Financing for COVID-19 health-related expenditures are estimated at CFAF 42 billion (0.8 percent of non-oil GDP), which are being implemented under a national contingency plan. Key measures include: (i) training of medical and technical staff, (ii) purchase of necessary medical equipment, (iii) construction of seven health centers in remote areas, (iv) construction of three mobile hospitals, and (v) securely managing entry points. Additionally, the capacity of Farcha Hospital in N'Djamena is going to be expanded and the hiring of additional health workers is in process. The authorities have also decided on a package of fiscal measures to help businesses weather the shock: (i) for SMEs, the authorities will, among other things, reduce by 50 percent the business license fees and the presumptive tax for 2020, (ii) tax breaks such as carryforward losses and delays in tax payments will also be examined on a case-by-case basis, (iii) clearance of domestic arears of about CFAF 110 billion owed to suppliers, (iv) a subsidy planned to the agricultural sector (0.3 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the simplification of the import process for food and necessity items, including health equipment, and tax exemptions for these items. Measures were also taken to alleviate the hardship on households, including (i) temporary suspension of payments of electricity and water bills for the lifeline consumption, as well as (ii) Replenishment of the national food distribution program (Office National de Sécurité Alimentaire, ONASA) (0.5 percent of non-oil GDP), (iii) the National Assembly adopted a new law on May 11 that establishes a Youth Entrepreneurship Fund (0.6 percent of non-oil GDP), (iv) payment of all death benefits due to deceased civil and military agents, indemnities and ancillary wages owed to retirees and payment of medical expenses for civilian agents and defense and security forces (0.1 percent of non-oil GDP), and (v) the national assembly adopted the law on September 26 that establishes the solidarity fund for the vulnerable population amounting to CFAF 100 billion. The 2020 supplementary budget, which includes the COVID-19 measures, was enacted by the Parliament in August.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308152023/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C3: US Embassy site is reporting that churches & mosques are open as long as prevention measures and social distancing is respected along with with the compulsory order for mask wearing.  I saw the the UK Government is showing there is a "state of emergency" still declared till 03/10/2021, but I also found on IMF.ORG that was updated as of January 20th authorities decided to re-open gradually stating no limit on gatherings.  Conflicting information, coding to no measures as 2 of the authorities out of 1 show that restrictions have been lifted as long as preventative measures are followed.  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194118/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/coronavirus  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194213/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210214194719/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C6: The US Embassy reports that “The curfew is from 2100-0500 hours in Guéra, Kanem, Logone Occidental, Logone Oriental, Mayo-Kebbi Ouest, Mayo-Kebbi Est, Moyen-Chari, Batha, Ennedi Est, the city of N’Djamena to Mandelia, Logone-Gana, and from N’Djamena-Farah to Guitté.” The page was last updated on February 25, 2021. TCHADINFOS, a local information news site also reports that the curfew in N’Djamena and other provinces of the country has been extended for 2 more weeks, from Wednesday, February 24, 2021, from 9 p.m. to 5 a.m.  - https://web.archive.org/web/20210227225208/https://td.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/    - https://web.archive.org/web/20210228002810/https://tchadinfos.com/politique/tchad-le-couvre-feu-proroge-de-2-semaines/
notes_C8: Entry rules in response to coronavirus (COVID-19)  Entry to Chad  Airports have re-opened for commercial flights. All passengers from the UK are banned from entering Chad until further notice due to the new COVID-19 variant.All international travellers need to present a negative COVID-19 PCR test certificate dated no more than 72 hours prior to arrival in Chad.    If you enter Chad and are planning to stay for 7 days or more, you will need to surrender your passport, quarantine at home for 7 days and take a COVID-19 test on the seventh day. Passports will be returned upon presentation of the COVID-19 test receipt. If you’re staying in Chad for less than 7 days you will not be need to quarantine.    Source: http://web.archive.org/web/20210308184644/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/chad/entry-requirements

name: Thailand
notes_H1: https://thailand.prd.go.th/main.php?filename=index
notes_H3: 23rd Jan 2021: No recent evidence could be found to suggest that Thailand has a comprehensive contact tracing system in place. The Thai government does use contract tracing Apps MorChana and ThaiChana .    https://web.archive.org/web/20210123121330/https://www.xn--b3czh8ayeuf.com/faq.html      A recent Thai PBS News article covered the APP: "A closer look at Thailand’s (non-mandatory) contact tracing apps"https://web.archive.org/web/20210109053728/https://www.thaipbsworld.com/a-closer-look-at-thailands-non-mandatory-contact-tracing-apps/
notes_H2: Testing is expanded to asymptomatic people in vulnerable groups, and to some random testing of the general population. However, it is still not generally available.    https://web.archive.org/web/20200511213623/https://uk.reuters.com/article/us-health-coronavirus-thailand/thailand-to-expand-coronavirus-testing-as-new-cases-dwindle-idUKKBN22J0HG
notes_C7: https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus
notes_C1: Schools in Tak province have been ordered to close indefinitely especially in Mae Sot District. Students living in Islamic communities were notified to 1)refrain from going to classes, 2) be accompanied by their parents and for parents to keep their children at home until the disease investigation for the community is clear.   https://ddc.moph.go.th/viralpneumonia/eng/file/situation/situation-no389-010264.pdf
notes_H6: 23rd Jan 2021: Regulation Issued under Section 9 of the Emergency Decree on Public Administration in Emergency Situations B.E. 2548 (2005) (No. 17) effective since 7th Jan 2021 and appears to be current states in part that  "1. Intensifying the Enforcement of Disease Prevention Measures: Competent officials,  communicable disease control officers and responsible persons of places, activities or businesses  shall ensure that customers, travellers and the general public strictly comply with disease  prevention measures, by maintaining social distancing, wearing cloth masks or surgical masks,  washing hands, checking body temperature, ..."  No further detail is provided as to where and when specifically masks wearing is required. This is a nation wide regulation.   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123115637/https://www.mfa.go.th/en/content-category/press-release-and-information-2?p=2  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123111659/https://image.mfa.go.th/mfa/0/mkKfL2iULZ/0904-64/%E0%B8%A1%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%A3%E0%B8%B2%E0%B8%84%E0%B8%A1_64/13-01-63/%E0%B8%82%E0%B9%89%E0%B8%AD%E0%B8%81%E0%B8%B3%E0%B8%AB%E0%B8%99%E0%B8%94_%2817%29_Eng.pdf    The Bangkok Metropolitan Administration released a statement on 21 January 2021 "Bangkok asks everyone for cooperation to wear face masks". In part it states "Mrs. Silpa Suayrawee Saengsoon, Permanent Secretary of Bangkok, revealed that due to information from many agencies that Wearing a face mask can help prevent the spread of COVID-19. The best and most economical Nowadays, people are keen to wear surgical masks in public or crowded places such as establishments, shops, bus stops. Including people traveling by the pathways In the morning and evening, which is an urgent time where many commuters have to travel to work or return to their accommodation. " https://web.archive.org/web/20210123120324/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114334
notes_E2: https://www.channelnewsasia.com/news/asia/covid-19-thailand-migrant-workers-left-out-unemployment-12637164
notes_E1: The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a statement 20th Jan 2021 "State Welfare cardholders have received additional funding aimed at helping them weather the economic downturn caused by the COVID-19 pandemic. The additional funding of 500 baht applies from January to March. Cardholders making below 30,000 baht a year will receive a cash subsidy of 800 baht a month, up from 300, while those earning over 30,000 baht but not exceeding 100,000 baht annually will see their 200-baht monthly financial aid raised to 700 baht. The state welfare cardholders registered for the subsidies will begin receiving them this week."         The Thai Government Public Relations Department released a separate statement 20th Jan 2021 "The Ministry of Finance has assured that online registrations will be available for the extension of the “Co-pay” campaign and the newly introduced Rao Chana, 2-month stipend campaign. Deputy Government Spokesperson Traisuree Taisaranakul said the government will soon extend coverage for the “Co-pay” general purchases subsidy program for an additional 1 million people. The Rao Chana campaign meanwhile offers eligible applicants a stipend of 3,500 baht per month for 2 months. According to Traisuree, registrations for the “Co-pay” campaign open on Wednesday, January 20th, while registrations for Rao Chana campaign are scheduled for some time between late-January and early-February. "    In statement one - The funding amounts per total earning amounts to not account for more than 50% of earnings.    While not a lot of detail could be found - The terminology "state welfare card holders" in the first release and then "eligible applicants' appears to suggest that not all workers are eligible.  Therefore changed to 1 Formal only or informal only.     https://web.archive.org/web/20210123095511/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=0&cid=2&filename=index
notes_C3: 23/01/2021 - Bangkok restriction on gatherings coded on on 21st of December was announced as being in place for a fortnight.  Additionally this appears to have been for the Bangkok Metropolitan area only.   http://web.archive.org/web/20210104062002/https://thailand.prd.go.th/ewt_news.php?nid=10520&filename=index     While not specifically mentioning public events, The  Bangkok Communicable Disease Committee Meeting No. 3/2021, relaxed restriction measures on 22nd Jan 2021. "For today's meeting, the meeting agreed to provide relief. 13 types of establishments can be opened from tomorrow (22 Jan '64) onwards as follows: 1. Arcade game venues 2. Gaming cafes and Internet cafes 3. Elderly care facilities 4. All types of race fields except the field Horse boxing 5. Property catering Banquet Location Including any other places that are similar. 6. Field amulets Amulet Center 7. Beauty Salon (Non-medical clinic) place for tattooing or piercing the skin or any part of the body 8. Exercise place, fitness 9...."  https://web.archive.org/web/20210123082710/http://www.bangkok.go.th/main/page.php?3-=&type=detail&id=114335    No other evidence of canceling public events could be found except for political gatherings. The Thailand Government Public Relations Department published a release on 19th Jan 2021 stating: "Government Spokesperson Anucha Burapachaisri, in light of the recent political gathering, disclosed that with the Emergency Decree and Communicable Diseases Act being enforced to control the spread of COVID-19, the Government would like to seek cooperation from the public to refrain from attending any mass gathering. While the Government has been putting utmost effort to implement various economic stimulus measures to relief the plight of people as a result of the current phase of outbreak, the least that it would want to happen is an increased number of infected patients, especially from any political gathering."   https://web.archive.org/web/20210123102347/https://thailand.prd.go.th/more_news.php?offset=20&cid=2&filename=index    Because it appears that there is a nation wide ban on political gatherings and it is stated that this is due to COVID-19, have coded G2 from 19th Jan.
notes_C6: https://ddc.moph.go.th/viralpneumonia/eng/situation.php
notes_C8: Phase 6 of the reopening began on August 1 allowing entry to certain non-Thai visitors, including: medical tourists, filming crews, Thailand Elite card members, foreigners who have work permits, foreigners married to Thai nationals and foreigners studying at educational institutions. The mandatory 14-day quarantine does not apply to diplomats, but they must get tested at the airport.  All tourists should have a negative test result within 72 hours of their arrival, go through a second test once they land, and stay in a compulsory quarantine of 14 days on arrival. If any visitors test positive, they should be quarantined for 14 days in a state hospital.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080024/https:/www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C2: Prime Minister Prayuth Chan-Ocha approved loosening restrictions from the first week of February to allow businesses and schools to reopen.  https://web.archive.org/web/20210209080024/https:/www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C4: Restrictions on all public gatherings  https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus
notes_C5: Public transport available, providing people social distance and wear masks   https://web.archive.org/web/20210308164400/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/thailand/coronavirus

name: Tajikistan
notes_H1: Diplomat argues that Tajikistan’s government has not proven itself to be an accurate source of information on the pandemic. The government perpetually reproduces the narrative that it is strong, able to face any challenge, and the pandemic has been no different. An RFE/RL investigation last summer concluded that Tajikistan’s official coronavirus statistics didn’t match reality and reporting on the reality has become increasingly difficult. Tajik authorities blocked a critical news website, Akhbor, in April 2020. Also, Tajik authorities changed the country’s Criminal Code to punish reporting “disinformation” on the virus. Moreover, on January 26 Tajikistan President announced that the country does not have COVID-19 cases and the country completely defeated the COVID-19. The President urged citizens to follow hygiene rules.   Links: https://archive.vn/GuRLt https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
notes_H3: No contact tracing policy has been reported. The country is celebrating the victory over the COVID-19. Link: https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
notes_H2: No testing policy has been reported. The previous publications of Diplomat suggested that Tajikistan has a lack of capacity to actually test for the virus in hospitals and the government pressures on staff to avoid diagnosing it. Thus the prevailing belief among analysts that Tajikistan’s official numbers are, at best, vast undercounts and at worst absolute fabrications.  Link: https://archive.vn/GuRLt
notes_C7: There are no restrictions on intercity or interstate travel. See: https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ (web archive no available, page updated last on September 3, accessed 17th September 2020)
notes_C1: Schools are open at all levels  https://web.archive.org/save/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_H6: Masks are required at all times outside the home and those who do not comply can be fined. However, due to a lack of economic resources, not all inhabitants can afford buying masks, hence indicator 3.  https://web.archive.org/web/20200907104155/https://www.currenttime.tv/a/tajikistan-masks-law/30674428.html
notes_E2: It should be noted that tariff increases on electricity, water, and communal services were postponed until end of 2020. Any policy on debt/contract relief has been found for January 2021.   Link: https://archive.vn/tPm0s
notes_E1: No policy has been reported. Since Tajikistan announced a complete victory over COVID-19, it can be argued that the government is not providing income support. During National Address to the nation from January 26, the President has not mentioned providing income support for those who lost their jobs due to COVID-19.   Links: https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE
notes_C3: On 31 January, Tajikistan celebrated a national holiday - Sada - by organizing public fairs.   Links: https://archive.vn/XnHgX https://archive.vn/89HsW
notes_C6: "There are no local restrictions or localised lockdowns in place, however you must wear a face covering in public spaces, including in vehicles. Breaches of regulations can result in fines or eventually imprisonment."  https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.gov.uk/foreign-travel-advice/tajikistan/coronavirus
notes_C8: All travelers must show results from a negative COVID-19 PCR test issued within 72 hours of arrival.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C2: Workplaces like bazzars and cafes are open. They are required to adhere to strict social distance and hygiene measures.   https://web.archive.org/save/https://www.imf.org/en/Topics/imf-and-covid19/Policy-Responses-to-COVID-19
notes_C4: "Religious gatherings and other large events are prohibited."  http://web.archive.org/web/20201231113810/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/
notes_C5: No restrictions on public transport have been reported recently. The US Embassy website from December 29 says that public transport is operating. Moreover, on January 26 Tajikistan President announced that the country does not have COVID-19 cases and the country completely defeated the COVID-19. The President urged citizens to follow hygiene rules.  Links: http://web.archive.org/web/20201231113810/https://tj.usembassy.gov/covid-19-information/ https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/L94MD https://archive.vn/An4AE

name: Turkmenistan
